The game that introduced me to the Roguelike genre. The game that made me love Roguelike games. The game that made me love Strategy games. The game that made me simultaneously adore and despise Random Number Generators. The game that took my heart by storm and raced to the top of my all time favourites list. The game that finally made me try my hands at modding. The game that made me realize that I relish masochism in videogames. The game that made me talk in Lanius-speak. The game that made me fear and worship Giant Alien Spiders. The one game that even after losing hundreds of hours to, I keep coming back for more. ... This is that game. I already lost over 1000 hours of my life playing, researching, modding, watching videos or otherwise discussing this game. If I had those hours back, I would gladly GLADLY lose them again.

Faster Than Light is quite an amazing little game. It looks over simplistic at first, but there are several layers to discover, strategies and random events to make every attempt to beat the game challenging, unique and a lot of fun (expect most attemps will fail). It quickly became one of my favorites in my library of 1300+ games.  This game is not for everyone, but if you like difficult turn-based strategy (combat is actually 'real-time with pause'), sci-fi, single player and roguelikes/permanent-death, you cannot go wrong with this one. It's definately not a game for those who only enjoy action games and mindless shooting and running. It takes a only a few hours to complete a game if you make it to the end, but you will probably have to restart several dozen of times before you reach that point in the first (unless you play in easy mode, which I never tried so I don't know).  That being said, it you are not turned off by anything I wrote, buy FTL immediately. Gameplay is absolutely fantastic and addictive.

You are constantly running into issues where you have to make hard moral decisions that will affect your progress in the game. I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys happiness. 12/10

'Just a few hit points on the hull, and these are the final moments of FTL. My sweaty hands press sweaty buttons as the flagship bears down upon the S.S. A-Hole. If only my Mom could see me now.'  Let’s start off with the basics — FTL is a Rogue-LITE. There’s permadeath, but that’s about the only thing that really connects it to the classic concept of a rogue-like game. In fact, I think FTL is basically its own classification. I’ve never really played anything quite like it before, and it was refreshing to see a new concept on the market.  Let’s talk about the pros.   FTL’s gameplay is super solid. So far, I’ve come across no bugs at all, everything works as it should. The tutorial correctly explains each mechanic, and they’re each so simple that I thought at first the game would be a dud. Oh boy, how I was wrong. These simple mechanics scale into a huge atmosphere of strategy, where each move you make could decide your life or death in the final battle with the flagship.   Just like in XCOM, you get attached to your crew super quickly, and when one dies it’s almost enough to rage quit. Each race manages to bring a different component to your crew, which again adds to the overall strategy.  The combat relies on your micromanagement of different weapons, and your outfit in general. It’s satisfying to find a weapons strategy that destroys the enemy. Thankfully, there isn’t just ONE strategy to choose from, although they all revolve around your opponent’s shields.  'One by one, my crew members are dead. The shields are down, the weapons turn orange, this is the end. But I know I just need a one more shot. I can do this.'  Them cons tho.  FTL does fall short in a few instances, and none bigger than the lore. If FTL could create a real world around it’s fantastic gameplay, the game would be SO MUCH BETTER. Also, the text-heavy encounters try to be physiologically difficult to decide on, but honestly it’s super easy to figure them out.   Another large shortcoming is the lack of weapon variety and quest variety. Even with the expanded universe I find quests that I’ve already done and are super easy to do again with my foreknowledge. I just can’t see myself replaying this with so little variety.  'One second. The weapon is charged, but so is his. They both fire.'

This is a long review, so if you just want a quick summary of this game please skip to  Results  and read from there.   Subset Games makes an amazingly epic choose your own adventure space combat game.   Similar to a storybook FTL: Faster than Light allows you to choose destinations to approach with each location giving you a dialogue with options explaining events at the chosen location.    Campaign:  You play as a federation ship whose mission is to fly throughout eight space sectors in order to deliver vital information to federation fleet. The rebels are taking over the entire space system and you must fight tooth and nail to achieve victory. In each system you will run across a variety of different individuals from Pirates, Aliens, Bandits, Slavers, Smugglers, Merchants, and Humanitarians who all trove the galaxy. As the game progresses you build a ship, stock it with a crew, maintain base systems, and complete quests. The end of the game is a three part battle with an monstrous flagship which unless equip can be near impossible. FTL: Faster Than Light is a fun game that’s highly addictive and keeps you wanting to come back for more. The combat is gripping, the constant threat of an oncoming fleet of rebels keeps you moving, and the amazing scenarios make you want not. This fantastic game although great has its limitations and may not be for everyone. FTL is a hard game, even on the easiest difficulty it is no cakewalk. Advanced Edition Content adds new items to the game adding more complexity and difficulty to an already hard enough situation.    Gameplay:  The game plays rather smoothly. Each “jump” you do acts as a turn and allows for the rebel fleet to progress further through a sector of the galaxy. If you and the rebel fleet cross paths you enter a battle, which if you play your cards right you can escape or even win. There is a steep learners curve, but once you’ve figured out the general game mechanics FTL plays rather easily. You have the ability to pause the game during any battle in order to maneuver troops and properly decide how to place your shots. The game asks you scenarios and the result of them are entirely dumb luck, so be prepared to take chances. For example you may end up trying to communicate with an alien race and get great rewards or an equal possibility is that crew member may die. The battles can be very intense and there can be situations where you are perfectly equip and the luck of where an asteroid lands can completely change a guaranteed victory into a struggling brawl.    Difficulty:  This game has a lot of luck involved, so about half of the difficulty in this game is the luck and not the skill. Although this may seem to make the game look bad, it offers variability that many games do not. You will be on your toes not just because of the difficulty from the actual skill of the game, but also because anything can happen and in one foul swoop you’re ship and crew will be gone. If you want examples of why please comment as I have many examples where I have lost because of luck, but don’t worry I also have lots of why I have lost because of skill as well haha.    Hints:    1)  Make sure you visit every possible point you can for each sector, fight off as many enemies as possible because every piece of scrap matters and you will need it all if you want to win.  2) Make sure you take advantage of your crew, the longer they man a station the more efficient they become at it. 3) It’s a good idea to have a crew member in every station that placing one in can provide a benefit to your ship.  4) The mind control device is probably one of the best ways to distract an enemy ship’s crew and help easily destroy the ships interior.  5) The enemy ships will always have weapons of equal charge time charged before you. 6) The best way to give yourself first shot advantage is the cloaking field, it is worth saving up for. 7) The Flagship has four guns, the best way to defeat it is to defeat the crewmember manning each gun. 8) In my opinion the best way to defeat the flagship is with as many flak cannons as you can get (and possibly a missle that teleports itself), the cloaking field, and mind control. This will allow you to control a crew member of the enemy ship, go invisible while you recharge your weapons, and garantee you hit through the flagships shields.  9) If you kill every person in the flagship an AI takes over which is a lot harder than if you just leave someone alive (try and kill everyone except one person that way you can use them with your mind control).     Results: FTL is an amazing game, but it’s not for everyone. The graphics are not top of the line and the difficulty level is high enough to make you want to strangle someone. FTL offers so fantastic fights that really keep you on the edge of your seat coupled with fantastic variety making each play through feel like a new game. If you quit a game it will create a save, but you can only load that save one time meaning that if you die you must start over. I recommend FTL, and would even recommend paying full price, but if get this on a sale it is definitely a steam-steal.   Pros: +Amazing depth and variety throughout the campaign +Option to play with or without advanced edition content +Loads of different weapons to choose from +Quests and distress signals to keep you invested in each sector +Choose your own path so you can preemptively target your gameplay. +Epic space battles that focus on managing both the interior and exterior of a ship.  +Many different ship designs, but good luck getting them unless you plan to invest several hundred hours into this game.  +Different sector types that offer different combat and elements.   Cons: -The choice results are random, there are a lot of take your chance situations. -The battles can be decided by dumb luck rather than skill. -The final boss battle (the flagship) is rediculously difficult. [for advice check the hints section] -FTL has a lack of resolution settings and in windowed mode it looks like is barely 1024x768 and does not allow you to make it larger.

FTL... Where do I start? Let me get this off my chest right off the bat: This game is going to kick your ♥♥♥. Even on it's 'Easy' mode, it took me multiple runs through the game before I even made it to the last sector. It took me countless more runs to finally defeat the boss, and let me tell you, the first time you defeat the enemy flagship it is immensely gratifying.  Everything about this game is fun. The combat mechanics and how you manage your ship is very clever, and you have to be constantly vigilant in a fight, lest your enemy get in that fatal hit on you. In a lot of the text-based encounters, there's a risk-vs-reward factor, where going in and say, investigating an abandoned space station might net you some extra scrap metal, but you might also lose your best Pilot in the process. The variety in ships you use and of those you can encounter is aplenty, and any number of different playstyles can be used with varying degrees of success.  The little things about it are great too: there's just enough background information to hold the plot together, while also leaving lots to your imagination. The graphic style is quite charming, and every note of the soundtrack works perfectly in tandem with what's going on in the game.  All in all, a great little indie title, for a very reasonable price. 9/10

It's not often that a strategy game takes my interest, but when this turned up in a Humble Bundle (which I bought because of Bastion, Limbo and FEZ) it blew my mind away. I had heard of FTL of course and had seen it in the Steam Store, but it never received a second glance from me because the main image for FTL looks so boring! Just look at it for a second; about twenty orange ships moving lazily across a planet. There's no sign of speed or that they're going Faster Than Light, and it gives nothing away about what the game is all about.  Maybe that's a good thing, because the game is bloody brilliant! You are the controller of a nameable vessel and you have information about the rebel fleet that is rapidly persuing you. Your ship has to travel through each area, making special Faster Than Light jumps between special beacon nodes. When you arrive at a beacon an event will take place, such as a battle, a trade or negotiations, where you choose wheather you will attack the ship, try to hide or even bring an alien crewmember on board. During a battle there's lots to do, which means a lot of work around the ship for your crewmembers (also nameable, although you'll probably get sad when one you named after your friend snuffs it). There are shields, weapons, drones, medbays and a reactor to power them all.  The soundtrack is lovely, as with a lot of indie games. When you enter a battle, the music for the current galaxy gets more intense, and will have you whistling all day long.   The great thing about the gameplay is that it can be paused at any time, even in the middle of a battle, so you can plan your next move. This is a great little aspect of the game, because it makes you feel like everything's happening at once and you have to choose your compromise, because this game is HARD. There are times when you feel like a pro and times when you wish you hadn't provoked the enemy, or wish that you hadn't destroyed a ship while your crew were still on board. A standard game of FTL: Faster Than Light can take about an hour and a half, and no two plays are the same. Give it a go!

FTL Faster Than Light is a rogue-like with the added twist of being set in space and based around ship management. The gameplay involves you mainly micromanaging your spaceship and crew as you travel through a number of random encounters trying to reach the other side of the map so you can deliver a warning to your rebel headquarters and defeat the final boss.  FTL is a game that relies heavily on it's difficulty, being much shorter than your average rouge-like. You manage a number of fairly limited resources as you slowly improve your ship and crew. You gather fuel, missiles and money and hope for new and better weapons and drones as your crew members gain experience in whatever field they are working.  It is a well made game and one I'm happily recommending but it's also a game that has some rather annoying limitations.  Your ship has very little customization options which makes repeat playthroughs somewhat dull, an unusual trait for a rouge-like. Choosing a different ship often yields much the same gameplay as even though your starting position changes a little, the only real change longterm is the configuration of the various rooms on your ship.  Another problem is the relatively short campaign you will begin to take note of once you've learned the basics and only the unforgiving higher difficulty gives it any sort of longevity.  All in all FTL: Faster Than Light is a nice little game, but it is also a game that needs something more before I'll agree with the underdog hype that seems to be going around everywhere these days. Perhaps strong developer support and a growing modding community will one day make this into the game it could be but as it sits now it is nothing special.

The line is, FTL is an amazing game, it's not for someone that doesn't likes its genre, but if you like Rogue Indie games, get this masterpiece. You won't regret it.

FTL: Faster Than Light is a game you have to see for yourself to understand. Not only is it a game, it's a spaceship simulator. Oxygen levels can fluctuate throughout the fight, and fires can erupt toasting your crew and burning more of the precious oxygen. How will you defeat your enemy? Will you light the oxygen room ablaze and suffocate them? Send boarders over and watch the chaos ensue? EMP their shields, and blow up the weapons? Better yet, how will you respond to that?  Will you send in your shields specialist to put out the fire, but leave your shields down? Will you lock the doors and cut of oxygen and suffocate the enemy? Will you be able to reroute your crew to get the shields back online?  Ironically, hilarious failures can be half the fun of the game. Whoops, forgot to close that door. Sorry pilot, didn't mean to suffocate you. Dang, forgot my boarders on the enemy ship!  The only flaws are the harsh learning curve, and the high difficulty can be offputting for some. Despite those minor nitpicks, overall, I give it a 9/10.

Not sure how to classify FTL in terms of genre or playstyle, as it's pretty unique. It's a roguelike space simulator where you control your crew and ship as you race through various solar systems towards the end game. An individual game maybe lasts an hour or two or until you die (can be much sooner), but while winning is the goal, trying out new tactics and combinations of weapons is the fun part of the game.  You control a few crew members in a ship with various parts. You can assign a crewman to pilot the ship, one to control the ship's shields, and have a third crew rotate between manning the weapons systems and doing ship repairs. When you get into a fight, your ship takes localized damage that interferes with your ship's functions in every way. Thus, combat is a game of maintaining your ship and taking out the enemy as quickly as possible to minimize the mayhem they cause. Sometimes your ship will be boarded and you'll have to determine how to kill the enemy crew who are breaking stuff and attacking your own crew while trying to destroy an enemy ship that is likely still shooting you. The game has a million tactical possibilities every playthrough and is wildly popular.  It's cheap, and if you've got enough patience to play a game where the journey is the enjoyment, not the ending, you'll probably like FTL.

Boy...  This is a tricky one.  I'm not going to NOT recommend it. It's a good game, that's for sure, and I don't regret buying it. I've only played 7 hours so far, but there's no doubt I'll sink in some more hours so... yeah, it's a good game.  But it's really not as marvellous and great and perfect as some reviews suggest. For one thing, this game does not have 'awesome random events'. The game IS one gigantic random event. There's really nothing you can do that you are SURE will bring in positive or negative outcomes. This total lack of control feels refreshing at times, but it's more frustrating than anything else in my opinion. Some randomness is good, but to me, things get old pretty fast when everything works on a dice roll.  Other than that, the game is pretty hard and unforgiving. Good change of pace, considering the amount of titles that get thrown at our face where actions have no consequences. So don't get too attached to your crew... you'll see them die soon enough.  So... yeah. I like this game. But it's not the game of the century. It got so much praise that I guess I'm just a tad disappointed. Actually, I see it more as a time killer, kind of like Eufloria (yes, I did just compare FTL to Eufloria. Go figure).  But hey, that's just my opinion. Grab it for 2 or 3 bucks on sale and make your own opinion, you probably won't regret it.

It's certainly addicting and fun, at least while you're doing well. Not to mention that using built-in exploits and leadership skills (read: tag-teaming boarders and fires, or luring said boarders into the med bay and fighting them with heals) can be pretty gratifying. However, I find a large margin of error to be the fact that it's just as fortuitous as, well, real space travel and war... in our present with our technology. Seriously, what kind of faster-than-light spaceship crew doesn't have anything better than a fire extinguisher? Why can't we isolate the cabins to vent oxygen only from the ones that are on fire? What material did they build it from that is so mysteriously flammable? And once you think you've got the timing of the weapons right and everything, and you've fully upgraded your shields and you've got decent weapons and a dependable dodge rating, the flagship puts up a kind of underwhelming fight... at least until suddenly your entire med bay is on fire and your crew drops dead because the system is too damaged for heals while you're still getting battered by the flagship but since all hands are on deck (and dying) to put out the stupid fire then your shields reload as slow as molasses in a vaccum and then you just die. Like you never even spent any time working your butt off to get your ship the best it can be, all those thrilling escapes and chases by the rebel fleet and the times you went six jumps with three hull points left and got to a repair station by the skin of your teeth, like those never even happened. And why? So you can do it all again. Nothing compared to the rush I get when I start off a fresh adventure, but it's agonizing to have to start from the bottom every time, considering this is the only permadeath-upgrade-your-way-unscripted-rpg game that I own or have ever played. No idea why I keep coming back to it, but I do and I can say I'll keep playing until it manages to really ♥♥♥♥ me off, and considering the way I died against the flagship on easy and I've still got the stomach to hit restart, I can't see myself rage-deleting the local content anytime soon.

There are few games that after a few hours of painstakingly doing everything to succeed, only to horribly die anyway, you think to yourself you cannot wait to do it all again. FTL is one of those games.  Overall, the game is not difficult. Overall, the concept of it is rather simple. Captain your ship from A to B, and do not die in the process. However, the choices you make as a new player will most likely kill your crew. Then, as you learn what is and is not a good idea, you get a little farther. Finally, once you think you have it all down, you get over confident and get your ship blown up anyhow. To add to it all, every playthrough is random (Rogue-like) so you cannot learn a pattern to 'win'.  In addtion to that replay value, you can get different ships that are unlocked through various methods, which do not necessarily make the game any easier or harder, but rather fit a certain playstyle better. Now, you could upgrade any ship to do any of these specializations (or all), but each ship also gets different crewmembers (each race has their own abilities) and layouts.  tl;dr Do yourself a favor and get this game!

Disclaimer: Have you ever wandered trough Steam, checking out several games, their screenshots, checking them out to add to the wishlist (or buying them right there on the spot)? Well, I did. It was a cold winter sales, Steam made a huge sale on this game, the screenshots didn't promise much but since I'm generally hyped for Sci-Fi ships games I went away and got it. Well, it was cheap, it was indie (I like to support indie developers) so it wouldn't be a total loss. I downloaded the game (pretty small download) and the next few hours of my life were lost in this brilliant masterpiece.  This game is an RTS/RPG mixture in wich you have your own ship and crew with minimalistic graphics, you travel trough space and sometimes you encounter some enemy ships (or you decide to turn hostile on them). You have to controll your crew and the game ends when they die. Pretty easy until here right? Now add up the fact that you have several modules on your ship, upgrades, money, fuel and ammunition. Getting more complex isn't it? Now add up the fact that you are prompted with most of the choices you have to do like, for example, you detect a ship who's requesting help, you go near it and they approach you with a question like: 'We got out of fuel, could you give us some?' and then they prompt you with 2 choices: a) Give them the fuel (and wander if they'll give you something when you reach a safe spot or maybe you're just a good soul); b) Kill them and steal their money and ammunition. All of this and much more, make one of the most fun, innovative and immersive games I've played recently.  Overall: 9/10 Words can't describe this game at all. It's a immersive experience without using pretty graphics. Using it's own originality it conquered a space among most of the AAA games I've played and I don't regret a single penny from what I paid.  PS: They upgrade everyone to Advanced Edition without asking for a single extra buck, +1 for that!

This is one of the most unique and fascinating PC games I have ever played. FTL provides a distinct, single player experience in which no two playthroughs are the same. Small and random scenarios that can help or harm your objective make the game play out differently every time. In a sense, this game harkens to the randomness and permanent deaths of a roguelike title while making no apologies for it's difficulties like the Demon/Dark Souls games do. The main focus revolves around getting from one end of the galaxy to the other to destroying the enemy capitol ship. The gameplay has you managing your ship, crew, and resources while transporting from beacon to beacon on a star map. It's at these beacons that the random scenarios make for some interesting events which often require you to make choices. Part of the allure of this game lay in the fact that few choices reap the same result. For example, answering a distress beacon doesn't always mean there's a friendly group waiting for help. Another part of intrigue lay in the plethora of options at your disposal concerning how you play. When opponents boarded my ship to wreak havoc I would simply send some of my shipmates to deal with them. In time, however, I came to realize that I had the option to strengthen my airlock doors so they couldn't break through them while opening the space airlock doors to suffocate them via a lack of oxygen! It's the little options like these that make for some truly open-ended gameplay. The dynamic soundtrack provides a great collection of science fiction-oriented themes which change according to the circumstances, and the simplistic art style conveys a lighthearted aesthetic which ultimately makes it easier to accept the reality of losing your ship over and over again. The Demon/Dark Souls games are gloriously difficult with a more realistic art style, but it has a save system that can be used after you die. (FTL's art style is appreciated in light of the fact that this game has a permenant death system.) Ultimately, you will get more and more invested in your ship the longer you survive and upgrade it, but I must advise that you should expect to lose your ship from time to time because of the nature of the gameplay. It's mindblowing how such a unique and successful game was born out of a 2-man developement team (technically 3 if you consider the music composer). Kickstarter has it's ups and downs, but this title simply would not have existed apart from it. If I had to rate it on a scale I'd give FTL a 9.5 out of 10.

Be warned: this part is lengthy, in-depth, unprofessional (in my opinion), and may contain too many spoilers to sensor. You can skip to the bottom summary if you want. Otherwise, continue reading.    General Description   In this sci-fi, rogue-like game, you are a ragtag crew of beings aboard a reconditioned ship of your choosing, attempting to relay critical intel to the Federation while the Rebels chase you across a randomly generated galaxy. On the way to Federation HQ, you will encounter strange and somewhat disturbing phenomenon that could mean the prosperity or end of you and your fellow shipmates. It is up to you to decide what is the best course of action as you navigate through this skeptical society torn by war, but you will insure a bright future for all who inhabit the galaxy if you manage to succeed in your mission.    Pregame   Right off the bat, the first things I noticed about the game were the impressive art involved and the superb background music. It is apparent that the developers spent much effort into creating the setting and its characters while keeping simplicity in mind, and the music could not be better matched for the scenarios incorporated. Very space-esque, very attractive.  Let's jump right into it. With almost every game started fresh, there is usually some kind of starting equipment to get you ready for the rest of the game. Now I don't expect to be pampered with the best ship in the fleet, but I didn't expect to get a junker with pee shooters either. The game even tells you so in the description of the ship, and is enforced when the game explicitly recommends playing on easy before being adventurous and trying normal. You do NOT want to go guns blazing on normal until you've got more of a feel for the game, but I'm not here to stop you from that and that's fine. Once you get a hang of things, you'll realize that the first ship is not a junker at all, but that the game is unforgiving for making mistakes. Additionally, other ships can be unlocked by completing certain achievements or by successfully completing special events, with each ship having their own unique attributes.    Gameplay   When you're done picking a ship and customizing your crew, you find yourself in the middle of nowhere with a message box updating you on the situation. After some fiddling with the controls, you discover how to jump to the next nearby beacon in the sector, expending some of your fuel in the process. However, you've neglected to properly allocate the energy supply of your ship and the work of your crew in balance, and find yourself toe to toe with a pirate ship charging its guns up for a first strike. Not the best way to spearhead the mission, but you'll be up to speed in no time with the handy tutorial at the main menu screen... which you're not at right now. Well, somehow you manage to persuade the pirate into sparing both your lives and receive a hefty supply of scrap, missiles, and whatnot.  Which brings me to the save mechanic... not the best way to save a game, but it does prevent cheating your way back from an unfavorable situation, something the game is somewhat dependent on since you will find out later on most beacon encounters are random. You figure that out quickly and wonder why the game doesn't pick up at the last checkpoint (hint: there are no checkpoints). At least this will give you time to check out the tutorial.  The tutorial is pretty simple and gives the basics on how to keep your ship from falling to pieces... not much else to say about that. Afterwards, you jump right back into the frey prepared and confront another enemy at the next beacon.    Combat and Aftermath   Combat takes place in RTS style as you attempt to capture or destroy the enemy ship, all while defending your ship from hostile fire and boarding parties. Strategic advantage can be gained by disrupting specific functions of hostile ships, with the same vulnerabilites applying to your ship, so keeping everything in working condition is generally a good habit to adopt lest you like being a sitting duck. With this in mind, you quickly dispatch your newfound foe and profit from what can be salvaged of the remains.   Weapon variety and distribution is there but not executed well.  Weapon variety and distribution is rather random. Sometimes you'll get the best weapon of the game early on but never actually use it; other times you'll find yourself with an over abundance of pee shooters (which, in retrospect, is probably good to start with, but should be traded in later on). Some weapons have similar names but require different resources as well, which can be somewhat confusing. Luckily, whatever you don't need can be traded in at a shop for extra scrap, which can be used to upgrade the performance of your ship to be better suited in combat, used as currency to purchase resources and equipment, or commited to repairs of your ship after a rather dangerous encounter.  Don't get me wrong, though. Not everything in the game is completely combat. Oftentimes you'll encounter other travelers in need of assistance, come across stray wreckages holding caches of equipment, or accidently stray too close to the stars. It's up to you whether or not you want to participate in these events, but keep in mind that, under normal circumstances, the odds are always stacked against you. That's why Bill didn't make it back to the ship in time.    Summary   In short, FTL provides a plethora of addicting and exciting, new content for players to enjoy, with each playthrough uniquely different from the last. While there are a few disagreeable methods implemented, some are there to prevent the experience from being shattered so the player's attention and enjoyment can truely be fulfilled without interruption.    Pros   - Great Artwork and Sound / Simple story and background - Permadeath feature / Temporary Save - Strategic / Semi-linear gameplay - Randomly generated encounters / galaxies - Player choice heavily emphasized - High replay value    Cons   -  Flawed weapon distribution  - Somewhat misleading difficulty settings - The occasional no-chance-in-hell playthrough   Grade:  9/10  I highly recommend this game.

I absolutely recommend this game. It's not the open world space game you might hope for (look to upcoming titles like  Limit Theory,  [ltheory.com]   Wayfarer: The Outer Reaches,  [brightspritegames.com]   No Man's Sky,  [www.no-mans-sky.com]  Elite: Dangerous,  [elite.frontier.co.uk]  or  Star Citizen  [robertsspaceindustries.com]  for those). However, despite that, it manages to pull off an incredibly intense space experience within the constraints it puts itself in.   You're the director of the crew of a ship trying to get from point A to point B while fleeing a pursuing Rebel fleet that has all but destroyed your Federation, yet you carry vital cargo that may somehow turn the tide. It's never entirely clear what that cargo is, as the story plays pretty fast and loose, as you explore some distant reaches of space, fighting pirates, helping other intelligent species as well as being attacked by them, and coming across some fascinating anomalies as you go from beacon to beacon and sector to sector until you make it to the final, eighth sector.   Throughout all this, chances are you will die. A lot. This falls into the roguelike genre that has been popular recently, but with the great difference of being scifi amidst a bunch of more fantasy style games. Albeit, if you'd like more scifi roguelikes you may look into  Bionic Dues  [arcengames.com]  for another recent scifi entry into the genre (unfortunately minus the space, but fortunately  with  the mechs!).  That being said, that factor alone makes it well worth purchasing in my opinion (though preferably from GOG or Humble Store), but even more than that is that with the recent introduction of Advanced Edition content, the game has only gotten even better than before. Toss in mods and the fun stories you'll get from close scrapes with death from various playthroughs, and you have countless hours of fun, many of my own not counted here from playing the DRM-free version more on the side.   Ask yourself, do you want to be able to have the virtual experience of suffocating would-be pirates or saboteaurs teleporting aboard your ship? Do you want to be saved by your enemy trying to hack an already destroyed subsystem incidentally shutting the doors to it, restoring oxygen in the rooms and allowing you to do repairs after you fend it off? Then you want FTL. Other space games may let you command fleets, but few let you manage the frantic internal affairs of the crew trying to hold everything together.

FTL, or Faster Than Light, is strategy game in every aspect. And that's what puts it up above some strategy games of today. Along with easy to learn, but hard to master controls, music that is masterfully crafted, and a ship progression system that urges you to level a ship in many different ways for greater results, the game has decisions at every corner! Along with the standard choice box (Oh hey, do the thing this way, or do it this way, and see what happens), the in game choices you make in battle are equally as important. That ship you just destroyed gave you lots of materials, but was it worth taking that missile to the face? Along with that, the scenarios are well written and give you a sense of urge to take risks! Or not. With a boat load of ships to command, a whole crowd of races with different advantages and disadvantages, a multitude of weapons and drones to arm yourself to the teeth with, it's up to you to make the right choices as a captain to get you and your crew to the end. And with increasing difficulty modes, that end goal just became MUCH harder to achieve. It does have it's flaws, though. The backgrounds and art, while beautiful, are stagnant. This dulls the game a bit in an aspect. While the great planet is behind you, it all feels dead. Having randomly generated maps feels nice, but apart from stars too close for comfort, colorful planets, and eerie nebulas, the whole game can feel very repetitive. This is a bit of an issiue when you play through it a lot. Things become a blur of clicking and you don't feel like you are immersed in the game anymore. Combat is interesting, but it's a bit slow to start. All in all, I would recommend this game to anyone specifically interested in what it is, a ship based combat RPG.

FTL: Faster Than Light is a real-time strategy... turn-based... space ship... Star Trek... simulator? In this game, you control a space ship that is on the run from the rebels with valuable information regarding them in the war between them and the Empire. As you can tell, this game takes a lot of elements of its lore from specific source material like Star Wars and Star Trek. In this game, by default, you control the space ship, the USS Kestrel, though other styles of ships are unlockable. You can rename your ship and the three crew members you get. Your ship has multiple systems that you must manage, such as Oxygen, Weapons, and Shields. You have to run away from the rebel fleet across eight sectors, all the while fighting other ships, trading with people visiting stores, and making decisions. The best part abouth the decisions is that there is always a possibility of a postive or negative outcome. Depending on the type of situation that you are in, you decide whether or not to try that decision. Theoretically, the game shouldn't take more than two three hours to beat, you'll die and restart so much, the game's lenght will probably triple. The game has a very nice pixelated art style that I love (hinting at the origins of my name) and the price is very cheap considering the quality of the game. FTL: Faster Than Light gets an 8.5/10.  -The Pixelated Gamer

FTL is a modern rougelike in which you embark on a journey across space, fleeing the ever - present danger of a pursuing rebel fleet. You jump through randomized sectors from beacon to beacon, encountering giant alien spiders, hostile space pirates, and everything in between. Strategy and luck come together in FTL's combat system. What do you do when your enemy disables your shield and then beams its crew onboard to wreak more havoc? Do you reroute power to your engines to increase your ship's evasion or power up the medbay to fend off the pesky intruders? What impresses me most about FTL is that it caters to a million different play styles. There are nine playable ships (eight of which must be unlocked), each with two different layouts. The game will do everything in its power to crush you, asphyxiate you, set your entire ship on fire until that fateful moment when your hull (HP) reaches zero and your journey ends. You'll laugh and you'll cry (mostly cry), but you'll always come back for more. FTL does a great job with the visuals (combining retro and modern themes while avoiding clichés) and the soundtrack is simply amazing. Definitely worth whatever they're charging for it nowadays.

In space, when you're all out of missiles, the fire from the engine room consumes the life support system, and the hull of the ship is crumbling around you, no one can hear you scream. That is, if any of your crewmates were still alive. They've been eaten by insectoids.  Game over.  FTL is a mix of roguelike-alike and chaos management, in space, aboard a fragile ship that looks remarkably like the previous n million that were sent to their doom in some horrible, regrettable fashion. You'll love it regardless - you're saving the galaxy, fighting the rebel scum, as you plot a galactic (escape) course to ultimate (unlikely) victory... you'll love it right up until it's fiery gibs explode and float off to join the growing debris of your many failures.  Depth of mechanics and instant high replayability make FTL a winner. There's no doubt lots of successful strategies, but appropriately for the genre, uncovering them is both challenging and fun. Even when you're screaming.

This is a fun game, but you have to go into it with the understanding that your skill level will plateau after about 5 - 10 hours, but that does not mean that you will be able to ever win the game except by sheer luck. You can lose from lack of skill, but you cannot win from skill. I have repeatedly lost on the final boss because I never got good weapons all the way through the game. Due to the way the shield system works, it is really helpful to have lasers that fire lots of shots. On one playthrough, I got a bunch of these and just totally dominated everything. On many other playthroughs, I didn't and lost.   In general, the weapons are really imbalanced, in large part because all of the missle and bomb weapons require missles, which are in short supply, so you can't use very many missle weapons. This forces you to use laser weapons most of the time. However, once you start using laser weapons, you probably want to jettison missle weapons because laser and missle weapons don't have great synergy (although there are ways to make it work), Most of the weapons are worthless and it's annoying to find stores in the game thathave three terrible weapons for sale. I think I will look for cheats that will give me higher odds of getting useful weapons and completely remove the terrible weapons.  In spite of these issues, I think it's a fun game and would recommend trying it out. But wait for a sale.

I've had enough exposure to sci-fi games and stories to know what to expect from this simplistic little spareship simulator. Get a ship, buy upgrades, build up a crew, fly missions and OH MY GOD I EXPLODED.  A lesson this game teaches quite early on is not to get attached.  It went against so many of my natural tendencies. I want to clear all the sectors. I want to get all the upgrades. I want to take care of my crew and get them fully trained. Tough, says FTL. You have to make some very hard decisions. You have very little time. Bad things are going to happen to you. They're largely arbitary. You're going to have to asphysixiate your crew at least once.  It's very hard. It's very fun. You will experience the ecstacy of having a rig that just chews through enemies and the agony of when the thing you were praying didn't happen happens and your (nearly) perfect ship goes up in flames.
Play this game! Don't hesitate! Just buy it!

I have an ongoing love-hate relationship with FTL.  On one hand, it's a brilliantly designed semi-strategy roguelike game where you take control of a spacecaft and it's crew. You'll visit star systems, fight enemy spacecraft, upgrade your ship, and make little 'do you help this person or that person' kind of decisions. The music is FANTASTIC and the learning curve is very mild. The storyline is very simple, but it gives reason to the way the game plays, why you have to be picky in what systems you visit, and such. And the game gives me the vibe that the designers didn't want to make a best-seller: They just wanted to make a fun game, regardless of profit margins.  On the other hand, it's a roguelike, which means that you'll suddenly be completely overwhelmed by enemies and lose. And it's not one of those losses where you think 'maybe if I did this differently..' No, you just get completely blown away with no chance of escape. And I swear this game 'cheats'...I'll be attacking some lowly enemy craft and my maximum experience gunner will miss with a missile. Then another. Then another. Meanwhile, the enemy shoots my ship twice with a junk weapon and blows two holes in the hull.  A friend used a cheat and gave himself a ship hull that could take unlimited damage and maximum money (called 'scrap'). He still lost because the game found some other way to overpower his ship and crew. I've come close to beating it, but only by a thread.  Yes, this game makes me want to break my keyboard in half. Then I'll have to buy another because I'll want to play again a few hours later.

This is a wonderful and unique game. You take command of a vessel racing through the depths of space to warn the federation of its impending doom. You must not only survive but upgrade your craft along the way in a myriad of interesting ways in order to arrive on time and then fight in the final battle against the rebellion. Each decision you make has a cumulative effect on your chances of winning. This gives the game great pacing and story, despite being different every time.   Whilst very challenging, the game offers you a wide range of choices regarding how you upgrade your ship and develop your own strategies, with a wide range of tools that can be employed in different ways. Despite the fact that you cannot move your ship in combat, the battles still feel deeply strategic and thrilling, with each type of enemy vessel presenting its own unique type of challenge. If you enjoy bashing your head against a wall until you finally break through and succeed then this is the game for you!

In Faster Than Light you captain a spaceship through several sectors, fighting to deliver critical information to your fleet. It’s rather uninspired but the gameplay is the important part. While it is definitely more rogue-like than -lite, there are ship unlocks that you can earn from completing different challenges and some of the unlocks are clearly more advantageous than others. The game plays in a quasi-turn based fashion. You chose the weapon you want to fire and where to aim it but they have to charge up a few seconds before you can fire. If things get too hectic you can also pause the game to think through your next few moves. As your fight through each sector you can get more crew members, upgrade your arsenal and make lots of “moral” choices to try your luck at getting a nice bonus. Though it sounds like there is a ton of content (and there is) I still found things getting a little repetitive after countless playthroughs. My only wish is that there was an official “Endless Mode”, I know it would eventually reach rather silly levels of power if you get lucky early on but I would definitely go back for another several hours to play around in a more sandbox environment.

This is a pretty good blend of real-time strategy and roguelike gameplay.  You're a Federation ship with vital information on the Rebel Flagship and its fleet, which you're running from. The objective of the game is to reach the 8th sector (the last Federation fort), then dig your heels and attack the Flagship head-on to defend the Fed base and defeat the Rebels. You'll warp across several sectors belonging to different races and factions - you can run into energy beings, slavers, pirates, more Rebels, rock men, slugs, giant alien spiders (stay away from those. No, seriously) and so on. Most of which you'll have to fight off, some of which you'll help, and all the time you'll have to improve your crew and your ship so it doesn't explode.   Here's a pretty good summary from Zero Punctuation.     'But I don't like RTS games!'  Neither do I, mostly. But the pause function makes this much more enjoyable - you can stop, look at everything, give orders, and power/depower systems as necessary. Far less stressful than having to watch an entire goddarn battlefield at once, right? Speaking of which, you don't have to watch an entire battlefield - just your ship and the enemy's, each with its systems and crew and weaponry - and on occasion a space hazard. Seriously, just look at the trailer. Simpler than most RTS games.   'Just how hard is this game? Plenty of other reviews say you'll die a lot.'  This being heavily 'roguelike-like', your ship WILL explode more often than not - it's a tough game even on Easy. That said, you can still unlock every ship on that difficulty without the game mocking you. Which I almost have.   'What is this 'Advanced Edition'? Do I have to pay for it?'  I'll answer the second question first: No! It's totally free, both for people who already had it and people that haven't bought it 'till after it got released. As to what it  is , it's basically additional content - a new race called the Lanius, new ships (both for the Lanius and some extra variants of the other ships), new weapons and systems, and more random events. It can be toggled manually in-game - if you get this game, I suggest you do your first 5 or so playthroughs with it off, so there's less stuff to learn in one go.   'How do you unlock stuff in the game?'  The first ship, the Kestrel, is free. It's a pretty good ship, with a decent layout and good starting weapons. The Engi ship is unlocked by reaching Sector 5, which is relatively easy to do - and it's horribly easy to use. The Federation Artillery ship is unlocked by beating the game, if I recall. Other ships are unlocked via certain events, some of which are more convoluted and circumstantial than others. And then you have reskins. The B variants require you two beat two of the three ship-specific achievements for the same class of ship, and the C variants (which are Advanced Edition-exclusive) require you to reach Sector 8 with the B variant of said ship class.

I'm a bit of a graphics snob.  The way I see it, there's a reason why we're updating our computers every few years, there's a reason why developers are pushing the boundaries of what the technology can do ..  .. because the perfect game - well, it's visually beautiful, engrossing, realistic, immersive.  SO  FTL .. it's not the perfect game.  I tried it on a whim, and I really don't regret it. If you park the retro graphics to one side, it's an interesting and addictive game. Just like plugging away your money in an old school arcade when you're a teenager, every time you lose at this game, it just makes you want to try it again.  As you command your starship, you are -not- Jean Luc Picard, sitting back, tenting your fingers as you study the situation with a calm mind behind a chrome dome. You're not even Captain Kirk, banging every female alien you can find, contracting god knows how many interstellar social diseases. You're on the run from a massive enemy fleet, and there's every likelihood you will die.  (probably in an inglorious way)  Even so, it's a good, fun game. When you get everything right - a good crew, balanced systems, good strategy, you really feel like you're on a space adventure. The random situations and variety of ships you can earn really make the replay value on FTL very strong.  So .. even from a graphics snob ... this game is *good*.

FTL hates you a lot, and wants you to fail. It also wants to give you hope, and makes you feel like you're definitely succeeding this time. It's probably the cruelest of the current slate of permadeath RPGs, but it's also one of the most enjoyable; the atmosphere and setting is striking. It will let you fulfill the fantasies of sitting in Kirk's captain's chair you never knew you had, and for a good time, maintaining and upgrading your spacecraft will make you feel like a god among peons. The game has you on a timer, though, and you will run it down. And then you'll be killed, viciously, and - more often that not - slowly, slowly enough that you'll think you could scrape through. If you do, for one time, finally DO manage to scrape through, though, it will be one of the most satisfying achievements of your gaming career. It's... it's a pretty big 'if,' though.

I could give you an actual review of the game with reasoning behind why I like it so much, but instead I think I'll let you read through the story of one of my playthroughs and see for yourself.   Once upon a time, there was a ship, appropriately titled 'The Loser.' The Loser really sucked at doing just about anything, but was given an extremely important mission for the Federation nonetheless, as the bureaucrats at the top wanted to save money. They were to go to the far end of the galaxy and stop the evil rebel armada. Among The Loser's grand crew was the captain, Lousy, who made the worst decisions possible. There was also Stupid, an Engi, who did nothing except what Lousy told him too, and then managed to mess everything up anyway. He liked to play in fire. Then there was his brother, Fred, the engineer. Fred was the only person who didn't suck at his job.  Moments after leaving the station, The Loser encountered a rebel ship, armed to the teeth with heavy weaponry. Lousy, being the lousy captain he was, decided to attack the ship. After a quick three minutes of 'battling' (devoting all time to hull breach repairs and attempting to put out fires) Lousy ran away from the battle, jumping into warp, and, despite the ship still being on fire, decided to answer a distress call form a nearby space station. The station was being attacked by giant spiders, so Lousy happily sent in his battered crew to take care of them. However, it turned out that Giant Spiders were, well, giant. Running and screaming for their lives, the crew almost made it to their ship, though Fred did take the opportunity to distract the giant spiders by throwing Lousy to be feasted upon by them. Lousy died as he lived: screaming and running from a bad decision he made.  Now alone, Stupid took it upon himself to claim the position of captain, much to Fred's dismay. Despite having taken heavy damage, Stupid opted not to go into a store for repairs, and instead went inside a giant nebula, whereupon they were taken by surprise by slavers. The slavers demanded one of their crewman as a slave, and, though Stupid clearly wanted to fight their 10x bigger ship, Fred was more than happy to offer up Stupid as a slave. Stupid initially refused, but, upon being told there was candy on the slave ship, eagerly agreed. Fred never saw Stupid again.  Happy with the new peace and quiet, Fred took the opportunity to make some smart decisions. He flew the ship into a store and had it repaired. Realizing he had no money left, Fred took the nearby planets, asking if anybody needed some mercenary work done. One small group asked them to destroy a rebel scout that had been harassing a space station nearby. Though he was initially going to deny the job, remembering how well their last Rebel encounter had went, the pay was too good. He made it to the outpost and, though careful strategy and manipulation of ion blasters and drones, managed to take out the enemy ship. He then immediately spent all his money on a scrap recovery arm, thinking it would be a great long-term investment.  Feeling good about himself, he took up a couple of other jobs that were fairly easy, and accumulated many resources. Realizing he had to make it to the next system before it was too late, he decided that he's done enough mercenary work for now, and flew full-speed to the next system, just before the rebels took over the one he left. Choosing between a Mantis-controlled system and a Mantis-controlled system, he chose the Mantis-controlled system. Stopping at a store, he considered buying a cloning chamber, but then shuddered at the thought of more Lousys and Stupids running around and opted just to get fuel. All was quiet for a while, Halfway across the system he found an abandoned rebel ship and stripped it of resources. He fought off a rebel scout quite easily, and, on a whim, decided to check out a distress signal from another space station. Their message came through; they'd also been overrun by giant spiders. Immediately Fred turned tail and left. There was no way he was going down the same way as the not-dearly departed Lousy.  As he left, he suddenly read a signal on his console; there was an intruder on deck! Arming himself with a laser, he cautiously made his way out into the main hallway, where he found a mantis begging for sanctuary from a pirate ship that he had just escaped from. Moments later, the pirate ship itself appeared, offering up a bounty for the Mantis's return. Fred contemplated, and realized that, while it would be smarter to return the Mantis, he WAS getting rather lonely, and imaginary friends could only do for so long. Besides, he had been able to handle every ship thus far with a few simple strategies. He responded by firing upon the pirate ship.  But it was a trap! The Mantis tore out his shields, leaving him unshielded and crippled before teleporting back onto the ship. Several drones came out of the pirate ship, protecting it from anything Fred launched. Fred immediately threw his own drones at them in hope of doing some damage, but they were reduced to scrap heaps in seconds. With his back against the wall, Fred decided that he had no choice but to get out of there, desperately firing Ion charges at their weapons while he powered up his engines. But they had too many weapons. Lasers cut across the deck; numerous hull breaches broke out on the other side of the ship, and fires were lit near the oxygen system! He couldn't fix that now; he just kept powering the ship's engines, hoping to get away in time. The oxygen system broke, and slowly the air grew thinner. It became nearly impossible to breathe. Still, Fred worked. Eventually, he was able to launch warp speed, and get out of there! The Loser came to rest in the middle of empty space, and Fred ran through various systems to repair the oxygen. Eventually, he did, but by then it was too late to repair the hull breaches. Oxygen was seeping out at a faster rate than ever. Desperate, he went locked himself in the Medbay, where he spent his last few seconds wondering how things might have turned out differently if he had jettisoned an escape pod instead of running around screaming. Yeah, I'll admit. I played it on easy. That doesn't mean it WAS easy. I died, time and time again. I eventually got to the point where I could consistently (maybe 60%) beat it, depending on ship choice and store luck. It didn't click with me, at first. Each play is different, even with the same ship. Sure, there are modules you always want to have for the final boss, leading to similar tactics for that specific fight, but the interesting part (for me) was balancing progression strategy (getting to the final boss) with preparation for the final boss, itself. These are often conflicting goals, since a ship built for progression might not be any good at all for the final battle. I think that dynamic, right there, is what makes this game so intriguing to me.  It's not for everyone, though. If you just want to play a casual spaceship simulator, this will leave you unsatisfied. If you want to play 'savior of the galaxy, against all odds', look no further.

FTL Is a game where you command a space ship whilst running from the rebel fleet towards their home base to destroy their commander, The Rebel Flagship. Let me tell you, that's not easy.  You start off with 1 ship. With it's own loudout, that's the same every time. To get more loadouts and more ships, you have to do certain challenges and quests, respectively. You can send your crew into different rooms to operate different things. You power up your FTL drive and warp to the next planet. Every planet has a different event. A store, a stray rebel, a pirate, a slaver, a ship in need, a quest. Any of these events are possible. Your choices don't really effect you story wise (as there's not that great of a story) but every decision you make can positively or negatively impact your ship. You might gain a crew member, some scrap (The game's currency), damage to your hull, etc etc. Take too long in any one sector and the rebel fleet will have caught up with you. There are hostile sectors, full of enemies with better ships but better loot, friendly sectors, full of random events that will most likely benefit you, and nebulas, full of, well, nebulas.   With all this I gotta say I LOVE this game. It's a lot of fun to play, probably on of my favorite indie games, Next to Terraria and Fez. I have only a few complaints.  1) THIS GAME IS SO FRUSTRATING. Sometimes you'll encounter a lot of bad things and you'll end up dying and be like WTF I had so much good stuff that run. 2) The Flagship. The flagship fight is like no other fight. Once you get to it's sector you have 6 turns to attack it or you lose. Which is fine. Here's the problem. It's extremely difficult. Every single fight up until now has been cake, for the most part. Nothing prepares you for this. You basically have to be able to go through 3 hostile sectors in a row and take no damage to be able to take on the Flagship, assuming you even make it there. THEN, if you can survive the Flagship's onslaught of doom and destruction and destroy it, you're not done yet. There's s SECOND part of the battle. Let's be clear. I've done about a hundred or so runs. I've made it to the flagship about 20-40 times. I've beaten part 1 about 15 times. I've beaten part 2 twice.  This game is sucks.  And I love it.  Oh and the music is great.

In short: This game is frustratingly difficult even on ''Easy'' Mode. Detailed explanation below. You have to perfectly know and manage every single aspect of exploration, timing, gear, upgrades, crew and battle from the get-go even on ''easy'' mode to stand any sort of chance against the enemy, not to mention the highly overpowered final boss.  The tutorial is shallow and insubstantial, teaching you only the bare basics and nothing else, leaving the bulk of mechanics and strategies for you to die over and google.  You can easily get to the final zone of this game in 30 minutes, wich will have the final boss catching you completely off-guard and unprepared.  The problems above are made even worse because said final boss is a good 2-3X bigger and stronger then the hardest enemy in the game and utilises pretty much every single game mechanic to hand you your ♥♥♥.  Basically, for you to win the game on ''Easy'' mode;  - The stars have to allign in your favour as to grant you enough favorable encounters for sufficient money to be able to buy the upgrades/crew/equipment needed to survive&kill the enemies&final boss.  - You need to know&understand all game mechanics and flawlessly time&coördinate everything you do.  Granted, if you do pull all of this off i imagine it's the best feeling ever, but the hassle involved just isn't worth it to me.  What was that you said? winning on normal mode? Pfffthahahaha no. FTL is similar to the old old old game known as 'Oregon Trail'.  Essentially, how the plot goes, the rebels are threatening to overthrow the federation, and you, as a federation officer, stole some vital information depecting how to defeat the rebels. The rebels learned of this however, and have sent their entire fleet after you. So you, in a manner of speaking, have to jet your ♥♥♥ out of there and back to the federation as fast as possible.  That's where this game starts. You are tasked with getting all the way to sector 8, the federation home base. On your way, you will encounter events, similar to the old oregon trail style. Some of them will be helpful, some of them will hurt, some of them will force you fight enemy ships.... a lot of them will force you to fight enemy ships...  The combat in FTL is similar to a strategy puzzle than an actual dogfight. You have weapons, shields, and evasion. Along with a variety of other weapons and utility devices. The basics of combat are simple... wait for your weapon to charge up and then fire it at the enemy. Depending on the weapon, it will do a certain amount of damage to the enemy ship to reduce it's hull (hp). When the hull reaches zero, the ship blows up.  What makes this game so great, however, is that there are a wide variety of weapons and tools you can use to help destroy, or defeat enemy ships.   Among those strategies, you can: blow the ship up, force it to surrender, set fire to the entire ship, suffocate them all, send a robot to kill everyone on board, or many other infamous methods. (My personal favorite is creating a hull breach in their oxygen room)   Along with the randomness and wide variety of combinations, this game is different and the same in almost every playthrough. Expect to die a lot when you are first learning this game.  The goal is clear, how you adapt and go about it is up to you.

This review is going to go against the grain... but it's my honest opinion here.  This game is a 2-d, Top-Down resource management game, that gives you variable resources, sporadic choices, and a forced up-tempo on-rails-like experience.  By itself, the game system is not all that hard to figure out. You get scrap, which is your main currency, to buy crew, supplies (like missles), and upgrades to your ship. You then fly from star to star fighting for or chancing upon more scrap and the occasional item or crewmate addition. You are forced to keep moving forward by a 'Fleet' chasing after you, so there's a constant pressure to not get caught by them. If you do, you're almost guaranteed serious damage to your ship or a game over.  So what's the problem then? Its the difficulty. Which has nothing to do with strats or skill. Its comes from the randomness.  Random encounters. Random events. Random upgrades. Random sector maps. Random... just about everything. You can have the best strats in the world, but if you don't get the breaks you need in bumping into the 'right' stuff, you WILL fail. Every time. In fact, failure is a lauded feature by the more zealous players of this game.  Also the final boss... it's the 'Rebel Flagship'... and must seriously be a troll move by the developer. You can have the perfect ship, with all the stuff that can wreck any other ship you encounter in the game... and just about beat it... when all the sudden it supercharges its remaining weapons and wrecks your ship. Super frustrating.  Lastly... the graphics look like something from a 90's PC game (think Ultima VI). I guess that adds charm for some. To me, it seems dated.  I guess one real positive from having low graphics is that the game has little to no loadtimes or overhead for interface speedbumps. Its all pretty much point and click, and is a fast play.  So if you like bashing your head on your desk every couple hours in abject frustration... play some FTL.

Clicking on Quit without saving will *also erase* the save point, so you end up starting over next time you start playing. This I found when I made a bad purchasing decision and wanted to redo it.  Be *very* careful what you do in this game. the save point is a useless one-off, and you're either stuck with whatever decision you make, or you're starting over from scratch. There is a lot to be said about this game. Sure, the graphics are simple and low tech, but the very engaging gameplay more than makes up for them. When you start playing FTL, you quickly come to realize just how unimportant the graphics are and their simplicity actually helps you. FTL has massive replay value, with every destination having a randomly generated encounter that will cause you to fight, run, repair, upgrade, assist, and or mourn your losses. Since FTL does not use an auto-save feature, there will certainly be losses, and death is permanent. So what else is there to do but start fresh and do better than you did the last time? Every run is an adventure, and no two are ever alike.

OVERALL: 8/10  I usually don't like Indie games. Cheap games like this usually suck. However, this was a real gem of a game to find. I got it on sale for around $2, but after playing it would have gladly paid the full price.   The concept of the game is amazing. Pure fun. Starship combat, with different weapons, subsystems etc. Your crew levels up in particular skills (shields, piloting, etc), over time, making you want to keep them. You can attack your enemies head on. With drones. Teleport boarding parties to kick some butt. Or just run away. You can then target each of your enemy subsyetsms for greater effect. They are shooting at you too much? Target their weapons. They threaten to get away? Target their engines! The possibilities are dammed near limitless.  Each game play is completely different. New things happen and the maps and events change with each play. While this is overall a good thing and helps replayability it's also a big weakness. The randomnisation can really tax the fun. A crew member may die randomly after popping into a new section (a wild disease has gotten loose on your ship etc). You may come across the giant ship of mega death that can outgun you and blow you up very quick. etc etc. The difficulty level is up there too....after 12 hours on easy, I still can't beat this game. I've made it to the final boss a few times, but I've gotten creamed every time.  Is it fun? Yes. Can it suck due to RNG occasionally? Absolutely. Will you have find and lose track of time? Yep. Should you buy it? Without question.

I didn't think I'd like this game, since it's Micromanagement: In Space! But it's a well-executed little game. First off, it's roguelike - crazy hard, ramdomly generated, permadeath, odds heavily against you. Even easy setting will find you blown up numerous times, especially while you're learning the basics. The graphics are pretty basic but they get the job done. The music provides a good space ambience. The replay potential is great since there are a number of ships and layouts to unlock and achievement or challenges to accompllish. The fun of this game comes when you get through the hard learning curve. Once you get the basics down, you'll understand what to do in most situations, but make no mistake - even experts lose or can have a run of bad luck as any game that's as RNG dependent as FTL can have a great run turn into defeat (my latest run with the Rock A cruiser). Conversely, you will also have runs which start out awful or look bleak and you'll somehow make it through which is a fantastic feeling. If you can handle the basic graphics, minimal story, and hard difficulty, this game is worth it and then some. I had never known what a 'Rogue-like' was before I picked up this game; I just loved the idea of being a starship commander. Not just some lone shmuck flying a fighter or a transport ship between systems; an actual captain, with a real ship with compartments, corridors and subsystems and a real crew to obey my orders. As soon as I realized that this game could let me do that, I grabbed it.   FTL is a challenging game, all the more so by the fact that you get only one life - when you die, you're dead - that's what a 'Rogue-like' game is. As in real life, failure means the destruction of your ship and crew. That's ok - the game is designed for multiple play-throughs, and a full game takes only a couple of hours to finish. As you must always stay one step ahead of the onrushing enemy, you can never unlock everything during a single play session, and a large number of unlockable ships provides incentive to keep playing again and again.   Combat is frenetic and nail-biting, as you must manage everything seemingly at once. You must keep an eye on your hull integrity, move your crewmen from room to room in order to repair damage and keep key systems online, even repel boarders who will otherwise wreak havoc on your ship. All the while you have to try to blow the other guy out of space! A wide variety of different enemy ships and armaments means that the same tactics will rarely work twice.   On top of everything, there is a multi-layered RPG system in place. Keep crewmen at one duty post and they will gain skill in that discipline, increasing your effectiveness. Scrap collected after each encounter must be used wisely - do you spend it all to upgrade your ship, or keep some in the hopes of finding a shop and buying new weapons? Keep in mind that you also need it to buy ammo, fuel, and repair your hull! There's never enough resources to upgrade everything to the max - you must choose carefully and decide what to focus on.

You must escape from the rebel fleet with a precious message, but with every jump you make into Hyperspace they are steadily closing in. Far from home, you must struggle through a capricious galaxy full of indifferent aliens and hazardous phenomena, where every resource is precious, and none is more precious than time. You are only one ship, they are legion.

Now that I have played some more of FTL, I'd like to give my current thoughts on the game: it still blows. Despite the game having many good concepts, FTL is a game that suffers from artificial difficulty to the max. You start off by setting sail into the deep ends of space. Sounds interesting, right? Unfortunately, that's where you begin to see many of the flaws of FTL, the first being the poorly implemented RPG system. Your crew members supposedly get better the more they use certain skills, but unfortunately, it doesn't really help all that much, so it's kinda pointless. Even worse is the game's balance in battle, as sometimes, the enemy has an advantage over you, even in the beginning level of the game. Worst of all is the game's lack of strategy. Yes, strategy is in this game, but luck is an even bigger factor here. In fact, luck IS the main factor of this game. Now, I know that rogue-likes have a luck factor, but many of them also have a skill factor that balances out the luck factor. This game, however, takes the luck factor way too far, and even worse is not being able to properly strategize and prepare because of the rebel fleet chasing your puny ♥♥♥ ship in space. The moments where you do get to strategize, which is during battle, doesn't help all that much, and battle that are easy tend to be boring as hell. The game is also repetitive, and not in a good way. The presentation department is also a joke. There's a good way to do wannabe retro, and there's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ way. FTL falls into the latter, containing mediocre chiptune music and really crappy graphics. Speaking of wannabe retro, how come this game lags? Seriously, this is a 2D game with ♥♥♥♥ graphics, not an FPS that requires you to have a high-end graphics card. In the end, the game is a lame piece of ♥♥♥♥ that is overrated by its fanboys, who probably have never played any other rogue-likes aside from this game and The Binding of Isaac.

FTL: Faster Than Light is a great game. Be warned before heading in, though. This game is tough. I've put over fifty hours into it and only actually beaten it once. That said the game is extremely compelling and fun.  The power managment system of your ship had me flashing back to when I was a kid watching an episode of Star Trek and hearing the Captain shout 'All power to shields, brace for impact!'. The Power system can lead to some interesting scenarios, especially when you're in a power draining nebula or your ship has been damaged. Do you put all power to weapons and hope your crew doesn't suffocate from the 02 system being off for too long, or do you put what little power you have into engines in hopes of escaping?  The resource managment is also an interesting mechanic that leads to many important choices. Do you beef up your weapons but leave your ship as tough as the average tissue paper, sink all of your points into armor and have a tank with a pea shooter, or do you attempt a balanced build that leaves your ship mediocre in most areas? Thanks to the randomness of the game you are often helped by random chance scenarios that give you a ton of spare scrap metal or new weapons and mods. Unfortunatly on the other side of the coin you have just as much of a chance that five Mantis warriors will board your ship and tear through your crew and you'll be forced to restart the game.  There are several different ships and ship layouts to be unlocked as well. If you're having too much trouble with the first ship, don't worry. After a couple of runthroughs you'll begin to unlock other alien ships that lead to very different styles of play. If you're doing terribly with the Kestrel Layout 1 then perhaps you'll do better with the Drone heavy Engi ship. The sheer randomness of the game is what helps its longevity, so don't worry if you have a bad playthrough. You'll get a great one soon enough.  Don't let the games difficulty put you off. Even if you never manage to beat this game it is still a ton of fun, and it is always sold at a deep discount during the Steam sales. Do yourself a favor and buy it.

This game is amazing for what it's worth. It's a rougelike with permadeath, so the campaigns are quick and brutal, but it's very replayable. It's good when you want to play a game but can't invest much time into the session. The game is very tactical, with the hard decisions you have to make stopping at planets and the combat. The latter in particular is ingenious, because there are so many different ways you can take down ships. You can simply try to blow up their hull, or board them for extra resources. Or, if you particularly evil, you can bomb their oxygen supply and just suffocate the enemy crew to death. Targeting substations like the weapons, shield, and previously mentioned oxygen supply will prevent the enemy from ultilizing them, but the foe can wipe out your substations as well. Also, it's all real time, so you have to be quick thinking to pull out. The best thing is that end game content is just as balanced as early game, so death's sythce is as present on the first world as it is on the last, and it is very present. One wrong move and your ship will go kaput.  However, unlocking new ships is a ♥♥♥♥♥, so don't expect to get new ships until multiple playthroughs in. How tediously long and random it is to get new ships is very artifical in difficulty and not dependent on skill. It's really my only major complaint for this game. The game can also generate some unfair situations. I've had boarding actions during solar flares (a random room catches on fire every so often until you leave the 'planet' you're on), which depending on where the flares strike and who's boarding (one species of aliens are immune to fire), can kill you quickly.  Also, the soundtrack kicks major ♥♥♥. Fits the mood of the game perfectly and is just good tunes in itself. Half the reason to play this game is for the music. If you're into buying game soundtracks, definitly do it for this game.
