Since there's a lot to manage and watch, there's the option to pause in combat and micro manage the weapons and systems you have. Though you have to be careful to watch whats going on with your ship and the attacking one.   The game is randomized with a number of events, though not very numerous. The shops are random too, offering different crew members, systems, and weapons. Using scrap, you need to make decisions on what to upgrade and what to purchase, and what you need for the future. If you don't have much of a variety, you might get overwhelmed in the future.  Be careful of the choices you make becuase they can either help you or hinder you, sometimes saving your ship and sometimes being the end of your little journey. The outcome of many events sometimes depends on the upgrades, systems, crew, and weapons you have. Luckily like mentioned above you can pause combat, if you are stumped in battle and need to re-think your strategy.  It has its downsides, though if you don't mind them, you'll like this strategy game. When you begin, you might end up going through a streak of losing and bitter battles. I write this as I struggle for breath in the thinning air of the engine room; alone and waiting for my inevitable death. Only hours ago the crew and I were feeling invincible with our impenitrable shields and powerful weapons. Our hubris was neglecting the physical security within our ship and forgoing our hand to hand combat training in favor of board game nights.  We were boarded by three thugs while exploring a new sector. Two of my crew died fighting them before the futility of our situation struck me. In a panic I ordered half of the ship's rooms to be vented. My weapons officer and I made it to the engine room. A wave of relief washed over me when the clamor of their havoc to turn to silence.   That relief turned to horror when I realized the brutes had managed to damage the door control and O2 systems during their rampage. I ordered my weapons officer to repair the damaged O2 system. He made it to the room, but before he could complete his task the lack of air overcame his senses. The insane ramblings of his oxygen deprived brain are the last words I shall hear uttered.

The Void Is Merciless. 10/10  It's brutal, it's strange, it's got psychic slugs and stone golem Klingons. Use every ounce of cunning, guile, and luck to fight and sneak and salvage your ship through the dangerous, randomly generated systems between you and Federation command, all while merciless Rebels hunt you like a dog. Fire mighty weapons, equip strange technology, recruit weird aliens!  The music is notable in its ambient appeal and comfortable long-term listenability, the graphics, while not high tech, do a wonderful job of telling you precisely what you need to know about what's going on in your vessel. The gameplay is intuitive, and you can even use some interesting tricks like putting out fires by venting air into space. The game's challenges can be cruel, unfair, and hostile, but you're a spaceship captain! Deal with it!  Unlocking new equipment and vessels, discovering new tricks and devices, formulating new strategies, scrambling to fix it when things go wrong... It's everything a starship command sim should be. My only complaint is the rebel fleet's endless and insatiable pursuit... Many times I've had to abandon my explorations to escape them, leaving behind possibilities and treasures. But that is of course part of what gives the game urgency and pacing... So it's more a personal matter.

The story is negligible but the scenarios are believable and tension is very much there as you progress and have to manage your resources and arsenal. Music is wonderful and really captures the atmosphere, or lack of, of space and has a beautiful serene feel to it but quickly shifts to tense battle music when confronted. Very fun game. Choose a ship, jump between stars, manage your ship systems and crew for maximum efficiency in combat or crises, customize your ship and crew, and stay ahead of the enemy fleet until you get to the end!  The main mechanics in the game are managing your power to systems to keep vital areas active as your ship becomes damaged or doesn't have enough power for every system at once. In addition, you can get more efficiency out of your systems by having the proper crew manage each system. You also get to target which enemy systems you can target with your weapons. Choosing wisely in any of these areas can mean the difference between victory and becoming a loose association of floating debris.  Each playthrough is relatively short, but the replay value is immense! You only start with access to one playable ship and you unlock the others by progressing in the game or by finding hidden quests. Each ship has several different designs available, if you can unlock them.   The game can be quite unforgiving at times with a random number generator. Do yourself a favor and start out on Easy until you figure out how it works. Don't let a little bad luck discourage you, it makes you better when you learn to prepare for it as best you can!  Good luck, and stop the rebel fleet!

So close, and yet so far from being a good game. I've tried to like this game. I've played it time after time, sure that at some point it'd click, and I'd suddenly gain understanding that would let me unlock the game's potential. I feel confident in saying now that that's just not possible.  I play roguelikes. I've got platinum god in Binding of Isaac, I've beaten Rogue Legacy and Risk of Rain. I've beaten Nethack MULTIPLE times. There's a trick, to all these roguelikes. When you begin, how well you do seems to be a matter of luck, of getting the perfect run. As you come to understand the game's mechanics, however, you improve to the point where almost, if not every run has the potential to win. The makers of FTL didn't understand this concept, clearly. They got as far as 'randomly generated' and stopped paying attention. You can be placed immediately into situations you cannot win. You can go an entire run without finding any upgrades or shops, until the federation fleet with 2 drones, 3 weapons & tier 3 shields is breathing down your neck. And of course, the entire combat is HEAVILY luck based. Yes, creators, it feels so good when 3 missiles miss in a row and the enemy tears my ship a new exhaust port in return.  There's also the matter of this game's idea of balance. Missile/bomb weapons are incredibly powerful compared to beam weapons. The tradeoff is meant to be a limited amount of ammo. So, you know, a limitation clearly not applied to the AI, who will happily send a couple dozen missiles your way, ignoring all that effort you put into your shields AND whatever subsystem it hits.   In short, FTL bills itself as a roguelike, and that's laughable. Play it only if you like gambling in a time-inefficient manner.

I used to like this game alot, it was fun and super hard when I was learning the mechanics. After way too many hours invested, I now hate this game more than any other game in existence.   I hate it because I now know every trick, every exploit, have beat the game with every ship on normal and all but 3 on hard. Yet I am still at the total mercy of pure sheer stupid luck.   Thats what ruins this game for anyone who wants to see hours of practice turn into skill, those who wish to learn and use their knowledge to succeed. FTL does not allow this to happen. You can be the most skilled player that ever lived and still a random number generator will determine if you win or lose.   The player might as well not even be present. You can make absolutely zero mistakes and still be subject to stupid dumb luck. It would not be very difficult to write an algorithm to play the game perfectly with no mistakes and perect timing, and yet the random number generator would still determine wins and losses. If you haven't watched Firefly, I suggest you do so now. If you HAVE, however, then enjoy this game, as it is basically as close to Firefly: The Game as it gets. Addictive, fun, beautiful, deceptively hard, and less linear than a swimming pool, even the thought of fighting for the Federation and not the rebels couldn't keep me away!  The existence of so many different systems and so many ways to upgrade existing systems leads to a huge variety of ways to play, with no one right solution to any problem. Don't like to get your hands dirty? Use drones! Shields getting in your way? Use missiles! On a budget? Just board the enemy ship and kill their crew! Want to kill the crew but all you have is this fire-bomb? Use the fire-bomb and watch as your enemies rush around desperately trying to put out the fires that just won't stop popping up in their Oxygen room.  The sheer amount of systems the player needs to manage (with the help of their meager but ever-developing crew) also adds a huge amount of complexity to the game. If a system gets damaged it will no longer function until your crew repairs it. The AI's targeting system is completely random, so you never know if that incoming Artemis missile will hit your door control and do virtually nothing, hit your sensors and blind you, forcing you to turn up your sound to listen for hull breaches, fires, etc; or hit your oxygen room and slowly drain your oxygen until your entire crew suffocates.  The various alien races all have neat little bonuses (yes, even Humans, which were buffed ever so slightly in Advanced Edition so they recieve training in the major systems faster). These bonuses are game-changingly powerful, but each and every one is extremely situational. The Mantis and Rock are the optimal choices for close-quarters combat, for example, with the mantis having increased damage and the rock having increased health and immunity to fire damage. However, the rock are painfully slow when moving and mantis repair at half speed, making them useless on a damaged ship. Zoltan have pitiful health but give 1 permanent power bar to the system they are manning, Lanius have boosted health and are immune to suffocation but drain the oxygen out of the room they are in, Engi are weaker in combat but repair faster, Crystal are slightly slower and tougher and have the ability to lock a room down temporarily, and the slugs have amazing telepathic powers that help them see inside enemy ships.  The game is balanced so that you will always be surviving just by the seat of your pants, unless you get extremely lucky. This expert balance system means that players are kept on their toes the entire game. As you upgrade and develop your ship, the scrap rewards scale up but the enemy ships get stronger. This balance system scales up so well that, especially on Hard mode, almost every situation needs to be carefully weighed, as most combat scenarios (especially late-game) are high-risk, high-reward.  Developing a strategy in FTL is something that happens during a game rather than before it, which is relatively unique in the Strategy gaming world. Yes, each ship's starting layout gives you an idea of how to secure a bit of scrap early game, but throughout the game you will be buying and selling weapons, drones, systems, augments, and anything else you can get your hands on in order to develop your ship into an effective fighting machine for whatever little scrap you may have in your storage. Effective strategies and knowing how and when to use each item can lead to amazing synergies, such as the use of a Glaive beam with a Weapons Pre-Igniter to cut down on its drawn-out charge time, or using ion weaponry to take down shields and then dealing damage with combat drones.  The beacons and sectors are randomly arranged, so no two runs are alike. You can find yourself hopping between civilian sectors one run only to find yourself barely scraping through two Abandoned Sectors and one Rebel Stronghold the next. The pursuing rebel fleet is another brilliant mechanic, as it encourages you to keep moving while scavenging as much loot as possible. The pursuing rebels are tough stuff, too, some even coming equipped with Chain Vulcans and level 4 shields!  Being a roguelike game, FTL likes to mess with the player. As a result, you will die very, very frequently. The great thing about FTL, though, is that it never feels cheap. Your death is always the result of YOUR actions. Not in an in-your-face way, either. You never just die because you forgot to check the corner for snipers or something (like in, oh, say, CS:GO), you always die as the result of a pleathora of factors working together. For example, you took way too much damage in the last fight and had to jump away with a broken shields system and half Hull points, only to jump straight into an asteroid field. The asteroids pelt your ship, damaging systems and hurting your hull while the pursuing pirate teleports a fire-bomb to your Oxygen room and an Intruder Ion drone into your weapons. The drone smashes a hole in the hull and makes short work of your weapons, leaving you defenseless, while the fire spreads from your O2 to the rest of the ship. As you send in your crew to put out the fires, an explosion is heard coming from the Oxygen room. The fires must have caught on an oxygen tank and exploded, and now your oxygen system is completely offline. This becomes a problem, as you had been trying to fight the flames by opening your airlock to vent the fires. Hoping to salvage the situation, yousend your crew to the Medbay and close all airlocks and interior doors. However, a shor from the enemy burst lazer strikes your medbay JUST as the first crew-member enters, killing her instantly. In a panic, you rush two other crewmembers to the oxygen room to put out the fires and repair the system before you all suffocate, and you send your pilot to repair the shields. You cross your fingers and pray, but the autopilot just can't evade the enemy's shots without the assistance of your pilot. You manage to get the pilot out of the shields room just as another fire-bomb incinerates everything inside, but while you were distracted your other two crew-members burned alive in the oxygen room. At this point, the fires have spread to every room but the helm, where you send your pilot in a desperate attempt to save him. At last, the final few laser shots from the enemy sail straight toward an exposed section of your hull, and your last three hull points are depleted. One last explosion rocks your ship as it is torn apart, ending yet another fantastic journey in FTL.  Overall, this game is very well made in every aspect. One of the best games I have ever played.

FTL: Faster Than Light is a very charming, challenging game. The basis is you are trying to outrun an impending threat, and along the way you collect items, parts, and crew members to help make you stronger in some way or another.  You build your ship any way you choose, and are given multiple ships to choose from, with even more to unlock later as you fulfill certain conditions in game. Tons of different weapons and modules for your ship, and even your crew can change how your ship runs, with all different kinds of abilities and traits between them. And that isn't even including the free expansion that comes with it, which comes with even MORE modules and weapons for your ship.  The basis of the game is always the same though. Make it from the left side of the map to the right without getting overrun by the enemy. You can TRY to fight them, but you won't win. Believe me, I've tried. You're just the lone federation ship, that is supposed to have some hope of taking on the rebel capital ship in a single fight, and if you play on even normal difficulty, it's unlikely you'll even make it that far before some ♥♥♥♥ing pirate ship with three defence drones and max shield upgrades ♥♥♥♥s you up on the third stage. The difficulty the game provides you in that uncertainty, is really fun to expierence.  However, after a few playthroughs of the game, this will start to die down as you come into the same random events, knowing which options are the right and wrong ones to take. And seeing how you will likely be dying often and will see the same events very often, it's pretty upsetting that the sense of total spontaneity is gone. If you decide to continue to play it after this point, it won't be about expierencing the game as the unique thing it was for the first 5 or so hours of play, it'll be more of a speed race to see how fast you can beat the game or seeing how badass of a ship you can customize if you linger around zones for as long as possible to get the maximum amount of scrap from it.  Overall, I'd reccomend getting this game if you want to find something truly different from most other games, at least for a few hours. If it's on sale or if you have the 10 bucks lying around, go ahead and get it. You probably won't regret it.

But even so, it's fun to play even though you will probalby lose very often.  It's a turn-based strategy game set in space. Decide which planetary system you want to 'jump' to, and the game advances a turn while you travel there. Once you arrive, you might fight a bad guy, or meet some friendly traders where you can buy upgrades and repair your ship, or you could be faced with a moral dilema that might lead to further combat, or potentially to a reward for avoiding conflict. Then you advance to the next turn.  You must balance the abilities of your ship while buying weapons and fuel, and you are constantly being chased by a superior force. In the end though, you must fight this force, and that's when I get my behind kicked! Ever wanted to know what it feels like to be the captain of a spaceship that's doing everything from fighting off alien arachnids to hijacking enemy oxygen systems and suffocating the crew to death? FTL: Faster Than Light might be the game for you. Aside from being the winner of the redundant name awards, This game is a roguelike-like with a simple learning curve and difficulty that scales from challenging but fair to punishingly unfair. Take note, though, that this game is pointedly not an open world game. It is procedurally generated and has branching paths, but there is no turning back, and you can only play out one scenario- a quest to defeat the rebel flagship. It's challenging enough that you'll probably go through a number of playthroughs before you even see the flagship for the first time, much less defeat it. But once you've done it a few times, you might find yourself wanting for something new, even if you haven't technically finished the game.

FTL is amazingly enjoyable, and even more frustrating. The entirety of the game is a battle between risk management and a bipolar RNG. Easy and normal modes are a painfully fun grind of learning all the ins and outs to unlock ships, achievements, and victories, but hard mode becomes a masochistic trudge toward arbitrary accomplishments. The creators of the game even admit that hard mode is intended to be won 1 out of 10 tries. If you ask me, this is a real killer. I don't want to put in an hour of really good gameplay to have RNG put me in a literally unwinnable situation. All that said, FTL is a hell of a fun game. Even in easy/normal modes at first it can be punishingly difficult, but not without a lesson learned from each failure. The most fun part of the game is unlocking all of the ships, and trying to defeat the Rebels with as many as possible. Once you really have everything unlocked, it can get boring and frustrating, but that really does take a while. For the price of this game, I don't think you can beat it. Just be ready to angry cry a lot. And swear more.

I absolutely love the rogue-style gameplay; the basic rules are simple enough to learn, but what makes this game are the decisions you make. You save all your scrap up and then decide that at the next station to spend it all on a new crew member, only to find out at the next station that you could have spent the same scrap on a ultra-powerful weapon that makes your latest addition look shameful; that's when you feel that pang of 'what could have been' that forces you to keep playing, your mind gets focused on the 'mabye next time I'll get an even better choice' and for that reason you play on. Even if you beat the game, it teases you with the possibility of having an even faster more successful run with a new shiny ship. This coupled with emotionally written randomized events which often put you in charge of making life-or-death choices really pluck the heart strings of what amazing gameplay should be. ... one minute you are flying brazenly across the galaxy and then you come to a fork in the road, one of the beacons is unknown, while the other is a distress beacon - after a quick thought you decide, against your better judgement, that you'll risk your damaged hull and exhausted hand-picked crew to be those peoples hero in their time of need. You click jump and launch faster than light to the distress signal only to find that it was a trap set up by a group of pirates! After less than a minute of heavy laser fire the pirate ship hails you, 'Please! Take everything we have, just don't kill us...please' they beg over the intercom. Mabye its just you and your over active imagination, but you SEE those pirates in your mind...cold, scared and alone they were most likely cast out of their home worlds and told to fend for themselves, driven to piracy out of despiration and probably not much older than yourself, its time for you to be the hero you came here to be; You hover over 'accept surrender' and then mis-click by a fraction of a milimeter. You watch with mouth slightly agape in dis-belief as a heavy laser mark II soars accross your screen, breaks through the enemy's weak shields and then smashes full-force into the flimsy hull of the pirate ship. In shock you imagine the vacuum of space robbing the young bandits of everything they had, even the right to one last scream as it instantly tears them into impossibly small shreds leaving only 14 meager pieces of scrap drifting in the black void of space as a remebrance of the hard and troubled lives those murauders led before they were smeared from the pages of history. Your ships crew retrieves the scrap with a robotic arm and then returns to their posts and awaits your orders. Within a matter of seconds everything had changed and it could never be taken back; you click jump, find the nearest beacon and take off with a heavy heart.

Highly recommended. This game requires a meta-strategy that is both thoughtful and hopeful, as luck is a large factor. The moment-to-moment action is definitely a micro management RTS, from the perspective of scace captain. There is much pausing-to-issue-commands here, where unpausing sets multiple commands in motion, in an Incredible Machine sort of way. WIth perma-death giving a sense of weight to every encounter, there are some truly awesome moments. Every square you visit is a dice roll though, and a lot of the success of a campaign (which lasts about three hours) is dependent on how lucky you were when you took each fifty/fifty shot to the next section of space. It's all about learning to adapt to what the random universe gives you, and it often ends in tragedy...but yeah. there are lots of extra ships to unlock and a ridiculous array of strategies for each type of ship/variant you manage to get. play on easy first.

I have enjoyed FTL so much I've bought it on iOS as well as Steam, and that speaks volumes on its own. I've not really dabbled much in the roguelike genre of permadeath gaming, but I like this. I think personally that a sandbox mode without the big chase would be a nice option (and with some easy modding this can be done, though totally unbalances the games difficulty which seems to be really well balanced naturally). I've played this game to death, to the point that sadly, I know by heart all the encounters and their possible outcomes. Even at this point I still find the game enjoyable. The combat and systems management are really engaging and challenging and make for endless fun. The fear of total irreversible death at any moment looms over giving a serious edge to every decision you make. When all is said and done, the modding angle give the game unlimited potential long after you've played the vanilla game to exhaustion.

Jump #8 - Ambushed by cloaked Rebel Interceptor waiting at the jump beacon. Life support took heavy damage. Charrl got sucked into space trying to repair a hull breach. Life expectancy on this mission kinda blows.  Jump # 9 - Ran across critically damaged civilian ship being pursued by bounty hunters. Bounty Hunters didn't offer a very good bribe so we killed them. Sadly the civvies all suffocated because their life support failed while we were busy fighting.  Jump #10 - Crew morale was low and our hull was in serious need of repair. Arrived at federation-friendly station. No life-signs aboard. Crew wiped out, Rebel AI running the systems. This galaxy sucks.  Jump #27 - Navigating a nebula when our Rockman weapons officer was mind-controlled and allows himself to be teleported off-ship by Slug kidnappers. They held him for ransom, which we couldn't pay. They blew his brains out right there on the viewscreen. Mantis crewman was quite excited to use the weapons console, we killed them quickly as vengeance.  Jump #42 - Mantis crewman revealed she had an illicit liason during a stay aboard a space station in the last sector, and became pregnant. Being in deep space and not really knowing how else to deal with a hormonal alien killing machine, I congratulated her. At that point she revealed her offspring had already hatched and was pretty much fully-grown. In honour of the alliance between our two people she named her child 'Daughter'. Truly, a strange people.  Jump #64 - Holy frak, that Flagship is HU-  ---------------------------------------------------  10/10, worth purchasing  The base game is fantastically easy to pick up, with layers of complexity for players to explore and experiment with as they play again and again.  THEN there's the free dlc, adding EVEN MORE space adventure madness to the mix.  AND THEN there's a large modding community, with tonnes of fantastic extra content created by fans, for fans.  This is a game that you can play for entire days without getting even a little bored.

Probably my GOTY for 2012, and I'm still playing it.  I think the most impressive aspect of this game is how well the role of chance is implemented, and finding all the little ways you can chip away at its influence. You're going to lose more often than you win, there's no doubt about it, and often times luck will play a major part in that. That being said, in all my losses, I've never felt like luck was the most important factor, because it can always be traced back, to varying degrees, to player action.   If you want a game that gives you the opportunity to make fresh decisions, and employ new strategies to deal with the situations you'll find yourself in, this is the game for you.

I had spent a long time looking at FTL before I had the opportunity to purchase it during the steam summer sale. As of writing this review the sale is still going on. I've played FTL for over 16 hours.  The first thing you will enjoy is that the game itself is appropriately short enough to be completed in a single gaming session. It can take longer if you wish, as you can pause the game and micromanage your units anytime you would like.   The rogue-like element is well balanced. Expect to lose and learn from it. It never seems too unfair. You may find yourself panicking at moments such as when your shields fail and an un-attended fire begins leaking into your engine bay.   You can already tell that it is sapce and sci-fi-ish, and I'm sure you wouldnt make it this if you don't like space games.   If this game looks even mildly interesting to you, prepare to be pleasantly suprised.

Amazing game! It's extremely difficult, but once you figure out how to attack and defend, it becomes much easier. However, it gets progressively more difficult the farther you move along in space and the final boss is no push over. Also, with the 'Infinite Space' mod, it adds a whole new way to play this game. Instead of being worried about being chased by the Rebel fleet (no not the peace loving ones from Star Wars), you can free roam around space until you eventually are murdered in a very crushing way. The only problem with the mod is that it has a weird difficulty spike not too long after you start. The music is also a fantastic part of this game and really adds a something extra incredible to it. It's both intense when you're in combat and very peaceful when just hovering around space. one thing that you should be warned of are the random events that happen through your journey. You may be that guy/girl who really likes to help everyone you come across, but sometimes, if you help that random stranger, you'll either get damaged or you could even lose a crew member, which is devestating. Your crew is your most important part about this, other than the ship itself of course. The best way to win a fight is to assign each person to a specific section on the ship and have them monitor/ repair it. If you don't, well then your weapons won't charge up fast enough, or you won't have enough evade skill to dodge a missile, so it really helps if you have someone at each section or at least the most important ones to stay alive. Overall, I would strongly reccomend this to anyone who really likes a good strategy game with a high difficulty and also someone who has always wanted to command their own ship and fell like somebody out of Star Trek.

While there is a simple story to follow, it's more about exploring the galaxy and seeing all the cool stuff you can find/unlock. While a typical game will take 2-4 hours, that only covers about 4% of the experience because of all the random encounters and secrets to find. Each ship has a semi-random assortment of weapons and systems which keeps each fight interesting. With each new playthrough, you can learn new tactics and evolve your strategy over time.   +Tactics  The game is deceptively simple as there are a limited number of actions you can take at any given time. However, FTL is one of the few games that really lets you employ unique and creative strategies with the tools you have at your disposal. For example, each room has an oxygen level. Venting your ship's oxygen supply can deter intruders and extinguish fires, but it makes it 'uncomfortable' for your crew. At any point, you can stop time with the space bar, letting you examine the scenario and do any commands you need to. This lets you try strategies that require split-second timing and respond to threats with lightning speed.   +Decision-making  Just as it says in the trailer, you can be the captain of your ship, and FTL executes this remarkably well. The level of decision-making you have lets you apply your own personal play style and strategies. Every decision you make matters for the fate of your crew. You must assess risk vs. reward with each encounter. Ambitious ventures into uncharted nebulas can reap huge rewards or end in death when an ion storm takes out your oxygen.   +Consistency of game universe.  You'll find yourself getting attached to your crew members and your ship. This creates an immersive experience and makes all the events happening in the universe seem important. There is a backstory behind each encounter that provides a little insight into the culture and the everyday happenings of the game's citizens. Each alien race has a definite personality that you have to take into account during interactions with them. Interacting with benevolent Engi usually turns out well, however wily Slug creatures are often less than truthful.   +Pacing  FTL is organized very well. Each node/'encounter' is about 1-5 minutes long, there's about 20 nodes per sector, and there are eight sectors. There are many meaningful choices you make along the way, as 'store' or 'distress' nodes are well marked and each sector has an overall theme/alien race associated with it. And, for the entire game, you're being chased by the overwhelming wave of Rebel ships. This gives you an experience that is fluid and fast-paced, but gives you the freedom to think and make your own choices. FTL is totally 100% gameplay, there's no cutscenes or cinematic elements that you have to sit through. (However, you really should read the encounter description or else you might miss something important or make a regrettable mistake).   +Audio/Graphics  The art style is really well done. The backgrounds and soundtrack really fit the mood of the game. The graphics are pixelated, yes, but there's a lot of detail and care put into it. It's not 'retro for the sake of retro', but a style that's consistent and perfect for this type of game, emphasizing readability and clarity over flashy or photorealistic visuals.  +Interface  If you look at screenshots of FTL, every one has a spaceship or two and some HUD icons around the outside. However, the amount of information they pack into every frame is amazing. The combination of audio cues and visual alerts keep you constantly informed without overwhelming you. Because every second counts, you can easily lose if you split your attention, but the interface is really good at showing you exactly what you need to know. Allowing you to stop time at will helps as well.   +Overall Experience  Seems like a bit of a lame topic, but it really needs to be said. It's such a small dev studio but it produced an experience that really feels 'complete'. You don't feel like anything's missing or done poorly. That's more than you can say for even big-budget games these days. Whether or not you enjoy the game, you must at least notice that the game is pretty much flawlessly made. It's detailed and nothing seems out of place.   Things You Might Not Like:    ~Difficulty  It's harder than most games even on Easy mode, a real challenge that doesn't always give you a clear path to success. The randomness doesn't help this at all. Going in, you have to be prepared to build up a ship you think is 'good' only to have it crash and burn in the next encounter. The defining moment for most people is if they give up before they start realizing the more nuanced strategies and tactics you have at your disposal. However, it is possible to win (even with some of the weaker ships you unlock).   ~Randomness  This turns some people away from the game (if not the entire genre). There are 'unwinnable' scenarios, especially if you pick a bad ship and it's early on in the game. However, if you get good, you can survive in any ship at least to the last sector. This is not a game that tells you a predefined story or sets you off on a path to a destination. It's a simulation with a bunch of random events, and really random stuff will happen to you in space.   ~Permadeath, with only one save state  You can only have one game saved at a time, and if you lose, the save is deleted. It's a system that fits with the rest of the game, but can be annoying. Allowing for multiple save states would ruin the randomness of the game, so if anything it's a necessary evil.   ~Exploration difficulties  Though much of the game is based on exploration, there are time constraints that force you to move forward rather than explore around the entire sector. Some nodes are just impractical to reach because you're being chased by rebel forces. You have to balance your curiousity for the game's universe with your need to stay alive. This is a bit of a struggle because the game shows you so much awesome stuff but doesn't let you visit all of it in one playthrough.   ~Filler Nodes  While there is a lot of content in the game, there are some nodes that are rather empty, or just have a token Auto-Assault Scout to fight. Almost every ship is unique due to the variety of weapons and configurations available, but many of the random encounters are pretty similar. Recognizing some of the same events occuring over multiple playthroughs can break immersion a little. These filler nodes can be helpful though after a tough encounter if they give you a break from the action. (e.g. ship is still on fire and you jumped away from an asteroid field and you have intruders)  Overall I highly recommend this game.

Game:  A strategic roguelike set in outer space in which you manage your ship and crew members in order to defeat the Rebel Flagship.   Good:  Great replay value with randomly generated sectors and unlockable ships and layouts; multiple winning strategies and gameplay isn't limited to one approach; constant danger forces the player to learn how to make the best of the current situation.  Bad:  Bad luck on many events can screw you over, even with skilled play; some weapons and augmentations are just awful and not worth using; enemy AI could use some improvement when targeting your ship.  Verdict:  High difficulty curve might put off some players at first, but it becomes very enjoyable and rewarding when you get better.   Rating:  8/10   Recommendation:  Try it. If you like it you'll get hours of gameplay for your money's worth; if you hate it then you'll be out 10 bucks at the most.

I don't think I've ever beaten a roguelike. This one proves to be no exception. I hope that doesn't hurt my review. I hope you guys don't think less of me because I can't get my ship up. To sector 7.  Anywho. Your character is a space ship. The crew is more inventory than anything else. You can even buy them at shops. It's like playing captain in Star Trek assuming that your crew listens to you. And assuming that Star Trek ships died every episode and you'd get a new ship to watch, instead of the same crew every time.  This certainly is a strong contender in the strategy/roguelike genre. The music is solid, especially if you like retro or 8-bit styled music. The graphics are not super duper shiny, but if you're coming from Nethack, you expected worse. And don't get me wrong, these graphics really reinforce their purpose. Shinier would probably have felt out of place in the genre.  Now then, if you're considering buying this, I'm sure you've already found out that the battle in this game is an interesting kind of real time. It's kind of the same real time that Final Fantasy 12 was. The game can go on and on if you leave it, but you can only act once meters have filled and you can pause while telling your crew what to do. For the record, I really liked Final Fantasy 12. And by extension I enjoy this game too.  If you're looking for a strategy game that will kill you, but can be overcome, this is the place to find it. It's got DF style 'fun' (read: dieing often) in droves. And if you like that, then this game will suit you well.

A lot of people like to throw around the word 'rougelike' for these type of games, and sure the term might be evolving into something else, but this game is not a roguelike. This game has a random generation aspect to it which is pretty good. The different sectors you go to are randomized, and all of the different lovations in these sectors will greet you with some interesting diologue, and more often than not some strategic space ship combat.  This is where the game really shines. The combat system they have used for this game works incredibly well combined with the random generation aspect of it. You will very rarely be using the exact same ship twice in a row, regardless of what it might seem like initially. The combat system allowes you to focus on whatever type of combat you want to defeat the rebel scum (among other naughty space baddies). Want to pass through the enemy's shields? No problem! Want to have a crew of combat ready Mantis people invade your enemy's ship? No problem! Want to make your enemies fight themselves!? No problem! All of the various part and pieces you can outfit your ship with allow you to use whatever meathod of combat you want.  This game is a strategy game, no if's, and's, or but's. It takes a certian level of skill to play on the harder difficulties, while the easy levels will still require some form of higher thinking to defeat any compatent foe. Throughout the game you will have to decide how to efficiently use your recources (fuel, missles, drones, and scrap). Scrap is your currency in this game and it will determine whether you upgrade your shields, or buy that really cool looking cloaking device from the shop, or maybe the hacking module, oh, or maybe... well... you get the idea. As you battle other ships, your ship will of course take damage, and how you deal with this damage is up to you! You will have to manage your crew members and make competent decisions on whether to keep your pilot at the helm in order to increas your evasion, or put out that fire that just burst out in your engine room.  If you are looking for a really different and unique ship combat style then look no further, because this is the game for you. I whole heartedly recommend this game, I have spend a good amount of time playing it both on my computer, and on my iPad. This game will have you coming back, with its awesome combat system, large variety of enemies, playable ships, and weapons, and all manner of quirky and hilarious diologue.   I don't much care to give our scores, but I will anyway and say that for me, this game rates an honest 8.5/10.

You know, normally I'd write a long winded essay of a review, but I'll keep it short.  Pros: Fun  Cons:  In all seriousness though, if you like games that require a little strategy to play but a LOT of strategy to win, then buy this game. This game will challenge you to think outside the box and sometimes you will only escape with a dented tin can of a spaceship, but when you finally beat the final boss it actually feels as if you accomplished something. Sometimes you may have to teleport a bomb into your own spaceship to kill an enemy boarding team...or maybe just open the air locks and wait for them to suffocate. Maybe you want to brute force your way through the enemy shields and annihilate them with sheer firepower, or you could use ion bombs to disable their weapons and oxygen systems and watch as they slowly suffocate without any way to retaliate. Will you hire a full crew, or only enough to keep your ship running and buy some repair drones to fix your ship systems for you? What will you do if your drone systems lose power and your pilot has to repair them, leaving your ship unable to evade incoming enemy fire? WHAT WILL YOU DO? TELL ME!  Obviously there is a little more to the game than just the numerous ways you can cut off the enemy's oxygen supply, but that's how I like to play. Does that make me a cruel person? NO! It doesnt. I swear.

The Game is just and simply, with one word saying enough, AWESOME. When you play through it the first time you will probably think ''Hm, well this looks interesting, but all the same in the end, right? You have to explore the whole galaxy endless times, sometimes make more risky decisions and dare your fate to see what comes out. Sometimes it is better to listen to others, sometimes not. Here an example. In one game i got boarded by pirates AND unlocked a new Ship-Design by listening to AI. So sometimes you just have to trust, even if it hurts. The whole game is just set about exploring, gathering and fighting. Over time you will find out special things, like a weakness in one races shield system, or what to do when you encounter friendly lifeforms on a planet. Also, unique equipment and personell can give you unique opportunities and ways to solve quests more efficient and increase your rewards. The Game is designed with a payload of love and brings you beatiful backgrounds and graphics (in retro-standards). Anyway, heres a little Sum-Up of how i think about the games pros and cons:  + You learn fast through trial and error, suited even for unexperienced gamers + Simple but intense fights with fair AI + An ever-changing Universe filled with mystery + Different ship designs to start a Game with can be unlocked through special actions and events + Balanced money-upgrading system + Pause the game whenever you want! So Savepoints or crap like that + Take a break whenever you want, pause fights to overthink your strategy + Well equipped merchants + Realtime dangers like asteroid fields, which dont stop after a fight is over + An ever pushing force on your back forcing you to consider your movement wisely + Insane earworm-soundtrack which you just can not get enough of + A retrofeeling comes up instantly, for all you Retro-Fans out there! (Including me) + I have never encountered glitches, bugs or anything else + Lovely Graphics + GIANT BONUS: IT'S CHEAP!!!  okay, even the best game has some flaws, I can only think of one though:  - The Boss is insanely hard to beat and is a giant boulder of obliteration on your road to victory  All in all, this Game is just awesome, and i would not consider it impossile to bring out a second part with even more features. Anyway, a definite must have for fans of retro and round based gameplay and definitely just a game which totally delivers the ''Just-One-More-Turn(Jump)-Mood''

I felt as though I had to post a review to this game. It is one of the greatest games I have played in recent history and takes me right back to my youth.  Is it for everyone... no, but then what game is.  Some people have posted reviews that criticise the difficulty, permadeath and randomness of the game. In my opinion it is these elements that make this game the gem that it is. Too often in modern games I find myself redoing missions and short segments of missions when they don't go the way I want, it is a hard habit to break (though one I'm trying to), and ultimately takes all the enjoyment out of some games and leaves my victory feeling hollow and meaningless.  In FTL I can't do this (that I know of and don't want to find out if I can!) and therefore every decision counts. Is it unfair sometimes... YES, but then so is life and you've got to ride out the bad to really appreciate the good. One of my favourite games of all time was Alex the Kidd on the SEGA Master System, and I never completed it. I'm sure if I could have saved the game I would have, but don't think I would look back on the game with such fond memories.  Some people will not be able to handle investing large chunks of time in a game to have their journey irrevocably cut short by chance or stupidity. If that is you DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!!! If however, you enjoy a challenge and find as much enjoyment in a good game whether you win or lose then give this one a chance. You will lose (often!!!), but when you win you know it will be worth it.  And as a parting comment, my favourite moment so far: when during a very successful run, with my ship nearly fully upgraded, fighting a particularly tough pirate ship, having repelled their boarding party through opening the airlocks and watching them suffocate against my bulkheads, we both simultaneously landed the killing blow with our beam weapons. Mutually assured destruction has never been so satisfying. And so one story ends, and another begins...

Hands down one of the best strategy indie games that have so far made it to our virtual shelves. FTL is simply brilliant: its simple yet pleasant art style accompanies with perfect armony the visual clarity needed to manage your crew, sending every crew member to the right system room of your space vessel at the right time. The RPG-like events and options render this game deeply interesting, shaping your ship, crew and gameplay more and more while you travel through the galaxy.  The objective is one and simple: reach your homeworld and defend your flagship from the rebels. How you will accomplish that, and indeed *if* you will manage to do it, depends merely on you. The enemies you will face will become harder and harder, requiring an increasing amount of thought and precision in order to cope with every situation and make the right decisions to gain the most at the least possible expense. I picked this one up for cheap during the summer sale. Now, I'm not actually a fan of slow, plodding strategy games like this one, but with a price tag of $2.50, I thought I'd check out what all the fuss was about. So far, that $2.50 has been Steam Summer Sale MVP, because while FTL can be a slow, contemplative strategy game, it is also so, so much more.  The best way to describe Faster Than Light is that it is a 'Star Trek Simulator.' You are captain of a Federation starship on an mission to deliver vital information about the Rebel leaders, all the while outrunning the oncoming rebel fleet. Using your wits, weapons, and a little luck, you attempt to complete your mission of crossing the galaxy via waypoints, having many adventures along the way. During your trip you will encounter hostile alien races, dastardly space pirates, or high-tech weaponry.  An aspect of the game worth noting is that the game uses a random event generator similar to The Binding of Isaac, making sure that Faster Than Light delivers a unique game experience with every playthrough. Also worth noting is that the UI, while seeming a bit confusing at first, is actually very intuitive to understand after the basics are understood. The combat engine is done absolutely brilliantly, especially with the inclusion of the option to stop time at will and analyze the situation. FTL rewards both careful preparation as well as snap decision-making, and it makes for a very enjoyable gameplay experience. And finally, the writing and storytelling are compelling enough to make repeat playthroughs worthwhile.  I have never played a game like this before, but it latched onto my brain in a very short timespan. It is just the right balance of difficulty, storytelling, and fun, and will keep you coming back for more.

Basic review and opinion: Amamzing game, with clever and fast paced action keeping you on your toes at all times during the game. As well the amount of ships and layouts to unlock make it so that you have so much to keep playing for. Personally I have put many hours into trying to get a single ship, and the payout is glorious when you finally do it. 8/10 Highly Recommended.  Frustration level: To say that this game is frustrating at times is a very large understatement, as at times it has made me want to throw my laptop across the room. This game is very rage inducing, but not because of something that IT did, most, if not all rage and frustration are from player mistakes. Yes it was a missle that killed you, but it was your fault for not repairing your ship in a shop. This game will force feed you humble pie, as you will begin to realize that it was not RNG or Bad luck that got you killed, but your own mistakes.  Gameplay (Mostly the combat and first impressions of mine): This game will look very bland and slow paced from a viewers perspective, having to wait for lasers to fire and watching as they only take a small block of health from the enemy each shot. However from a players POV the game is much faster paced, as not only do you have to keep track of so many systems and crew, but you also will have to send crew all around the ship to repair and activate weapons/shields/etc. The game takes a little while to get into, as for veteran players will feel bored with the beginning grind in the first sectors, while new players will feel like they are drowning in things they have to memorize and do. However once you reach about sector 4 or 5 the game picks up drastically, as the real race begins: Your ship is now running out of the fuel you had in the beginning and you are running into battles with much tougher ships, and you feel as though your next jump could be your last with every click of the mouse. This caught me by surprise my first playthrough, and I got horribly murdered by a massive enemy, and I sat back in my chair wondering what the heck happened. The other large part of the game is the Risk/Reward evaluation that you have to do at every choice. Some are obvious, turn over a crew member or attack the ship. But ones like the giant space spider station will always have random results, sometimes you get some scrap and useful items, other times your crew will die and you are left missing a person. This type of thing overshadows the entire game, making you feel cheated at times.    But with all those things put together with an amazing soundtrack this game is a wonderful thing to pick up for something to do, and you will not be dissapointed. Unless you hate roguelikes or risk/reward situations, in that case avoid this game like the plague, as most of the game is Risk/Reward. Well worth the money, and even more so when it goes on sale.

For anyone who has watched any series of Star Trek and dreamed of being the captain growling the phrase, 'Lock photons on enemy weapon systems and  fire ,' this game is for you. FTL does not replicate the positional combat of that perennial sci-fi series. Instead it replicates the nitty, gritty details of crew and ship management. Shuffle crew around to react to different dangers, from boarding parties, fires, and hull breaches. Manage power to ensure the right mix of offense and defense are presented at all times. Even open and close specific doors to manage the air supply in your ship. It is all here in a fast-paced, but manageable, package. Engaging to a fault this game will have you thinking, 'Just one more round,' many, many times into the night.

FTL isn't everyone's game. You lose far more often than you win. I've played it for around 12 hours so far, and still haven't beaten it.  But therein lies the devious appeal of this game! As one of the last ships loyal to the Federation, you carry information vital to overthrowing the Rebels who have taken over the galactic scene. You must weave an intricate dance to keep them off your tail, while trying to earn enough scrap to upgrade your ship. In the end, there is only one way out. When your engines are on fire, your shield system is disabled, and the nefarious alien boarders have you cornered in your own med bay, you will find yourself cursing that you didn't upgrade your blast doors instead of purchasing that Hull Laser. In the very next scene, after you somehow make the jump with the last surviving crew member, what do you find? A random weapon floating in space! This game is as addicting as it is sadistically merciless, and will keep you begging for just one more bloody turn!

Every playthrough will be different, but all will be fun.  Managing your ship's systems, crew, and resources is captivating and filled with tough decisions. Anytime you find yourself feeling safe fills you with both the pride of accomplishment mixed with apprehension knowing that the next jump could undermine the key to your strength and have you counting down the seconds until you can escape.  Acheivements are well made and challenge you to try different strategies, and an easy mode provides a good alternative to what can sometimes be a punishing difficulty.   I guarantee that after every loss you'll be smiling and kicking yourself about that one decision that you could have made differently and changed the course of the game. As any good roguelike should make you feel.

Let me begin this negative review by saying that there are plenty of positive aspects of the game; game play, sound, art design, writing, pretty much all of the major benchmarks. Lots of games miss the details, but this one doesn't; instead, it misses the big picture.  Why do people play video games? To have fun. Oh sure, there are other reasons, such as comedy, education, or beauty, but that's the primary one. This game is not fun, it's frustrating. A random number generator with worse odds than any casino is not fun. No checkpoints or some other means to reduce lost time is not fun. No method of tracking how much of the story you've seen not at all or for the umpteenth time is not fun. For some people, these things are fun; give them an option. For me, they are in the way of enjoyment and make the feedback loop of desperately looking for story you haven't seen, an opportunity to get that achievement, or to get to the end without the RNG dropping 5 bomb ships in a row on you an exercise in frustration.   This game is for a people are fine with grinding over and over against random odds to a victory that is more luck than actual skill. I am not one of those people. I am one of the people who would like to explore its rich content, but am sadly stymied by the sparse player experience options.

I really, really, REALLY want to give this game a positive review because of the fact that it is very well polished and quite fun to play, but the fact is is that I simply cannot. There are some downsides to it that completely ruin this game for me and have overall forced me to write a negative review.  But let's talk about the good parts of this game first:  1. The gameplay is pretty fun. It's very unique (at least it seems that way to me) and it keeps you wanting to come back and play it over and over again just for the thrill  2. It is very polished. I have not seen nor run into what even appears to be a glitch, bug, etc.  3. Every event is randomized so you'll never have the same two adventures twice, ever. Which makes it very interesting.  Now let's talk about the bad:  1. This game is extremely difficult. Being a new player, I decided that I would play the game on easy so that I could get my bearings and learn to play the game. To this very day I still have not even come within half-way of the first boss. Let me repeat myself: I have played this game on EASY difficulty SEVEN times and haven't even completed HALFWAY to the FIRST boss. Now I've completed some difficult games in my lifetime (The Impossible Game, I Am Toast, QWOP, etc.) and I have never, ever run into a game that is more frustrating than this one.  2. Remember when I said that events in this game were randomized, well I wasn't lying. EVERYTHING in this game is randomized, and it doesn't matter what level you are or where you are in the game, you will either run into a very easy challenge that you can breeze by at the beginning of the game, or you can run into a very difficult challenge that will show absolutely no mercy no matter what level you are. For example, I had a crew of four people, I took them to a planet that apparently had a pirate near it, so the pirate attacked and we easily destroyed his ship and took his wares. We then travel to the next planet where a pirate mothership literally fires four rockets at us at the same time and sets half my ship on fire will simultaneously destroying my oxygen supply and ultimately suffocating everyone on board to their demise: this happend right after the fourth planet I visited...on easy. DISCLAIMER: I love challenging games, but when you run into something that isn't even fair and you lose hours upon houirs of work because of one stroke of bad luck, it kind of ruins a game for you.  3. Unlocking things in this game is a b*tch. I read that you can unlock new ships by visiting planets and helping other people, or by defeating the boss, but when you can't reach the boss and you can't find any of the planets that have the new ships on them, it kinda defeats the purpose of even having unlockable ships. Basically you're stuck with the default ship for a really long time, unless you get lucky which is basically what this whole game is about.  ALL-IN-ALL  I would recommend this game to someone that likes a challenge and likes managing their own ship. I would NOT recommend this game to someone that doesn't like to put lots of hours into a game and then lose all of it in one fell swoop, or someone that get's angry or frustrated very easily, or someone that simply likes to play video games but hates starting things over and over and over again. Trust me, this game isn't bad, but unfortunately Steam won't allow neutral reviews, and I'm leaning more towards negative anyways.

A pleasant enough game if you don't mind such absolute randomness that the sense of challenge is ruined. Even on easy difficulty the game is notorious for absurd surprise attacks and seemingly arbitrary changes to the established rules.  The constant pressure of being pursued leaves you with never a moment to explore, regroup, or restock. This would be fine were it not made possible by the use of one impossible sci-fi trope (warping about willy-nilly from star to star) while countless others are omitted. This makes a novel premise for a story, but it's exhausting in a game where dying means starting over from the beginning.  It's this last element which makes me smirk a bit at this game's marketing as a roguelike. There's no going back up the steps, hurriedly reading a scroll, stopping back in town, or spotting a hopeless situation down the hallway and finding an alternate route. A good roguelike can do without some of these things, but leaving out every one of them except permadeath and bad luck launches this game out of that category entirely, and lands it squarely in the realm of Oregon Trail and the most obnoxious Choose Your Own Adventure fare.  Buy it for the beautiful soundtrack, which is about as good as Dustforce and maybe better. Better yet, just buy the soundtrack.
While I wish there were more main storyline quests, I like it for what it is. The speedruns and challenges on Youtube are really cool, and I wish I could play without using the Space Bar.

Date: 2/26/16 Review Number: 28  Game: FTL: Faster Than Light From (Creator Publisher): Subset Games Played On: Laptop Steam Price as of Review: $9.99 Total Time played: 45 Minutes Review:  Next game on the randomizer was one on the significantly shorter list of my personal collection of games that I didn't purchase while on deep sale or as part of a bundle. I don't recall now exactly how I had heard of the game in the first place, however I do distinctly recall knowing that this was a game I could totally end up playing long term. And lo and behold that has generally been the case.  Now the premise of Subset Games FTL: Faster Than Light is more or less a typical space opera sort of thing, you are a lone ship, fleeing a great and terrible army in your spaceship towards some sort of base at the end of the map, at which time you give the secret to a military hub only to have them tell you that they don't want it and that it's your job to destroy the enemy’s secret weapon anyway. One would wonder why they didn't just tell you that at the beginning of the map, but regardless you can still take all that time traveling inexorably rightwards to build up your ship with numerous types of weapons and sundry to make the job slightly less impossible when it happens. The game is largely text based, with most of the game's story communicated via dialog boxes, and combat more of a point and click adventure game than a space battle, but the fighting still manages to keep you entertained, not dragging on too long to be annoying, but not so short as to seem to be tacked on at the end. The game is very roguelike, with each star system having the possibility of throwing you a bone with some nice loot, or a pitched battle with a pirate battlecruiser. You definitely can feel the hand of the random number gods all over this game, and in many circumstances you will most certainly find yourself backed into a corner regardless of having done everything right. But the game does take great pains to not make the game seem completely unfair, and even the longest streak of bad luck really just seems more like you didn't do enough to make it work than any sort of random chance. In the end, as far as roguelike games go, I can safely say this is probably my second favorite, blending strategy and gameplay in a simple game that you can jump right into, get blown apart a few times, then feel like you've learned something, only to get blown apart a few times anyway. Buy.  Game’s Fate: Kept. This game works brilliantly as a quick and easy time waster and a long and drawn out roguelike. Buy/No Buy: This game will not appeal so some people, for many different reasons. All those people are horrible. Buy.

FTL is probably one of the most humbling games out there. One moment I'm flawlessly annihilating the sophisticated Rebel fleet with my advanced weapons and shields, and the next everything is all flames and destruction due to a nearby star and a lowly pirate. And yet these losses make me feel like I'm the captain of an awesome space vessel in a sci-fi movie like Star Trek, commanding my crew, managing my systems, and suffering the consequences of bad decisions. While your choices in events can be rather unpredictable, you also make many decisions in combat which determine the fate of your crew and your ship. This is one game I just keep coming back to.  Pros: -Runs on my junkheap of a laptop without any effects whatsoever. -LOADS of replay value and variety. -Advanced content for when the original version gets old. -Sightseeing the galaxy while being chased by an infinite, bloodthirsty Rebel fleet. -Doesn't require a lot of dedication to be fun. -Upgradeable ship and mini XP system for the crew.  Cons (But not really): -Enemies are sometimes ridiculously overpowered (but hey, that's part of space fighting). -Makes me press the space bar when I play other games in an attempt to pause. -Effective if you're trying to procrastinate. -Still can't get through the first few sectors on Normal. Honestly, the only real issue I have with the game is the random outcomes of some events. This may not be a problem for other people, but I'm personally frustrated sometimes when I make the same decision in an event twice with the result varying in extremes from getting some valuable scrap to losing a key crewmember. But, again, that's part of adventuring in the unknowns of space.  FTL is worth your money and your life!

It's good. Really good. How good? REALLY GOOD.  FTL is a game that piqued my interest way back when it first came out. Somehow this game gives the video game experience of a classic, 80s-era space 'Choose Your Own Adventure' novel.  Take your ship with its small crew and meager weaponry, and make critical decisions, attempting to survive pirates, pulsars, and the occasional giant spider, all with a deadly rebel armada right at your heels. Do you fight, or run? Is it worth the reward, or will you risk losing crew? Do you take down that rebel ship, even though it's bringing food to innocent refugees? Take the moral high ground, at the risk of failing your critical mission?  Surprisingly, FTL is quite extensive in the weapons and systems your spaceship can obtain. What flavour of laser gun do you like? Multi-shot, quick charging, slicing beam or even chaingun style? Or do you want disruptive Ion guns? Shield ignoring Missiles and Bombs? Maybe swarm the ship with attack drones, or even ignoring all that and teleporting over a boarding crew and mind controling the enemy.  Small hint: Learn how and when to use each of them!  I've played big production space-sim, rts, or turn-based games that have less gameplay options than this simple top-down 2D rogue game.  All that said, it is also unforgiving in it's gameplay, at a level where one might bandy the words 'Nintendo Hard' or 'Ninja Gaiden on Hard Mode'. There's a learning curve in this game, and it goes beyond knowing the stats of your weapons, crew or enemies. You can't plow through the game picking a single tactic or weapon combo and expect to win in the slightest. The game gives you a wide array of tools, and expects you to use them all in varied combinations to win. Learning to recognize the combos your playthrough is giving you, and responding to the events and enemies you find, or picking the path that best fits your combo or situation, really is how to play this game on a winning level.  Seriously, do not expect to breeze through this game like most other current games. Expect failure in your learning process, and learn to love the 'Aha!' moments, where you suddenly realize a new level to the game and can't wait to test it out on your next playthrough.

One of the best independent games that I've played in the last few years. Although FTL is only single-player, the sheer amount of variation and unpredictability that you will find in this game is remarkable. It is not an easy game, and I spent something like 30 hours on FTL before finishing it even on the easy difficulty setting (which is not even remotely easy). The developers have spoken about the difficulty in FTL before, describing it as a 'suicide mission' where you are the captain yelling at mechanics to get the engines back online. That is very much what FTL feels like: it is a frantic struggle for survival.  In practice, the game operates a lot like a board game, which makes sense since it was inspired by a board game called Battlestations. If you enjoy strategy games with a high degree of difficulty, it's hard to beat FTL. One really nice thing about this game in particular is that it will run on any kind of setup you might have: PC or Mac, and there's even an iPad version available.

I've dumped a lot of time in this game, both on tablet, drm free versions of it, and every now and again the steam copy. It's about a ship captained by you taking information across a hostile and unfriendly galaxy to your superiors so you can help stop a coup by a large and well armed military faction of the fractured government you owe your allegiance to.  In practical terms, this is a rogue-like. You have a ship and crew which is outfitted with the minimum equipment at the start of the game. You take the ship across a randomly generated sector, exploring, accruing more upgrades and crew members until you reach the sector exit. You choose which of two sectors you will go to and then repeat the same thing again with harder enemies further stressing your resources. You are being pursued by a large fleet which will gradually occupy more and more of the sector so planning out your route to the exit and what side paths you can explore is important to staying in good shape. Once you reach the final sector you face a boss battle in the form of a large, nasty ship, with three forms revealed as you destroy it.  Combat is real time with you choosing where power will be allotted, what weapons to use, where weapons will target on the opposing ship, what stations your crew will man and what repairs they do on damaged systems. As you gain scrap, the currency in the game, you can upgrade your ship's abilities, buy new weapons and systems at shops, and repair your damaged ship. It's important to balance risk/reward so you don't waste too much scrap on repairs. It also keeps you thinking if the next jump is worth it, can you explore, or should you run to the exit before the fleet catches up to you.  Not every game presented is winnable, particularly in the harder difficulties. I don't see this as a problem, part of the appeal is to see how far you can make it if you can't complete the game and to see how well you can do with what resources you have at your disposal. There are lower difficulties for more casual players to enjoy the game and harder difficulties for people who think the game is too easy or just want to face a tough challenge.  The easy to understand and accessible mechanics of the game combined with the amount of depth, in the events, resource management, and builds you can make for your ship make this a wonderful game and probably one of the best games on Steam and on Tablets - if you have one.

FTL is probably one of the most humbling games out there. One moment I'm flawlessly annihilating the sophisticated Rebel fleet with my advanced weapons and shields, and the next everything is all flames and destruction due to a nearby star and a lowly pirate. And yet these losses make me feel like I'm the captain of an awesome space vessel in a sci-fi movie like Star Trek, commanding my crew, managing my systems, and suffering the consequences of bad decisions. While your choices in events can be rather unpredictable, you also make many decisions in combat which determine the fate of your crew and your ship. This is one game I just keep coming back to.  Pros: -Runs on my junkheap of a laptop without any effects whatsoever. -LOADS of replay value and variety. -Advanced content for when the original version gets old. -Sightseeing the galaxy while being chased by an infinite, bloodthirsty Rebel fleet. -Doesn't require a lot of dedication to be fun. -Upgradeable ship and mini XP system for the crew.  Cons (But not really): -Enemies are sometimes ridiculously overpowered (but hey, that's part of space fighting). -Makes me press the space bar when I play other games in an attempt to pause. -Effective if you're trying to procrastinate. -Still can't get through the first few sectors on Normal. Honestly, the only real issue I have with the game is the random outcomes of some events. This may not be a problem for other people, but I'm personally frustrated sometimes when I make the same decision in an event twice with the result varying in extremes from getting some valuable scrap to losing a key crewmember. But, again, that's part of adventuring in the unknowns of space.  FTL is worth your money and your life!

Very good minigame. The game takes about 2-3 hours to complete, there are no saves or checkpoints - you lose, you start again (although you can copy a save file). The game can be started in one of 10 different ships, each of which has up to 3 different configurations with different starting weapons, crew and internal room layout. Starting ships/configurations have to be unlocked first.  In game, there is a lot of randomness – if you are unlucky, even if you make it to the final fight, you won't be able to defeat the boss. You collect weapons/items/ammo, fight in random encounters, do random quests, encounter space stations where you can trade the items or hire extra crew of different species. During the fight, you have to balance the energy usage between different systems, move the crew around to fix breaches, extinguish fires or fight enemy intruders on board. You can also open external doors in your ship to suck out the oxygen to deal with fire or intruders. At the same time you have to use your weapons such as cannons, laser beams, rockets, drones, boarding drones to destroy enemy ship or kill all their crew – you can even teleport your own crew on board of enemy ship. It's really helpful that you can pause the game at any time to plan your actions. I forgot to add that you crew gets experience with everything they do and you can upgrade most of the systems that you have installed in the rooms of your ship.  Nice music is an extra addition.  For the price of about £7.00 the game offers tens of hours of fun. It is definitely a good deal.  Finally, I don't remember seeing any bugs in the game, it's quite well polished.

Overall, it's a solid game and worth the price.  To give a brief synopsis: FTL is a game where you have full control over a starship and its crew. Your goal is to get your ship from one side of the galaxy to the other by warp-jumping through countless star clusters which are sub-divided into individual star systems. Each time you jump into a new system, you are given a random encounter. Usually its a straight-forward combat encounter. An example of a more interesting encounter would be finding a damaged space-station and making the decision, as captain, whether to ignore them and continue with your important objective, or send your crew into a life-threatening situation. In those cases its up to chance whether you are rewarded for succeeding, or you may fail and lose some of your crew. You also must maintain your supplies while collecting scrap which is effectively currency to upgrade your ship.  I agree with some of the criticism that the random nature of encounters can lead to frustrating defeats after an otherwise near-perfect game. There is also a low skill ceiling because of this. On many occasions your level of success is gauged by the roll of the dice rather than your skill.  At the same time, I also appreciated this because, as in Star Trek, a starship captain must face a no-win scenario at times. It some ways, this element makes the game feel more gritty and realistic. More unpredictable. I like that element in games. I would have appreciated more of a balance between skill and randomness. Maybe remove the pause feature and force the player to develop twitch reactions and have certain actions on the ship have a more tangible effect.  Another issue is the repetitiveness. Around the time I write this review, about 8 hours, I feel I'm beginning to see encounters repeating. Combat is also becoming a chore.  The low skill ceiling and eventual repetitiveness hold this game back from achieving longevity.  Still, I feel there is a minimum solid 6-8 hours of very addictive and fun entertainment to be had here. I highly recommend it to star trek fans or anyone who likes captain-simulators. I give it a 7/10.
